name: Introduction to Financial Accounting
description: Provides knowledge of core business concepts in financial accounting following generally accepted accounting principles. Emphasis on understanding the primary objectives, principles, and users of financial accounting, analyzing basic business transactions and understanding their impact on financial statements, and defining and identifying the basic elements and content on each financial statement. Prer., MATH 1030 or MATH 1040 with a grade of “C” or higher, Business students only. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

name: Introduction to Managerial Accounting
description: Provides knowledge of core business concepts related to selected financial accounting topics and basic managerial accounting, including basic financial statement analysis, the analysis of product, service and period costs, and the role of accounting in the planning and control of business enterprises. Emphasis on problem-solving skills supported by appropriate analytical quantitative and qualitative techniques for tactical and operational decision making. Prer., ACCT 2010. Coreq., INFS 1100. Business students only. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

name: Intermediate Accounting I
description: A comprehensive analysis of the practice of financial accounting and reporting by public corporations to investors, creditors and other users. Includes analysis of standard setting, accounting theory and generally accepted accounting principles. Emphasis is on the purpose of financial statements with a focus on income determination and asset valuation. Includes the use of spreadsheets. Prer., ACCT 2010 and ACCT 2020 with a grade of “C” or higher; or ACCT 5500. Coreq., INFS 1100 and FNCE 3050 or Graduate standing. Business students only. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Intermediate Accounting II
description: A continuation of ACCT 3010 with focus on liabilities, equity, and special areas, including cash flow statements, leases, pensions, income taxes, and earnings per share. Includes the use of spreadsheets. Prer., ACCT 3010 with a grade of “C-” or higher. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Cost Accounting
description: Cost analysis for purposes of control and decision making. Analysis of cost behavior, role of accounting in planning and control, and managerial uses of cost Accounting data. Includes use of spreadsheets. Topics of current interest will be discussed, including activity-based costing. Prer., ACCT 2020 with a “C” or higher;  or ACCT 5500.  Business students only. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Advanced Managerial Accounting
description: Application of advanced managerial accounting information for planning, decision making and evaluation. Topics of current interest will be discussed and may include analysis of pricing, cost allocation, balanced scorecard and capital budgeting that relate to corporate decision making. This course includes learning through technical content, cases, creation and use of spreadsheets and current scholarly research articles in cost related topics. Prer., ACCT 3110 with a grade of “C-” or better. Business Students Only.

name: Individual Income Tax
description: Analysis of basic concepts of federal income taxes such as income, exclusions, deductions, and property transactions. Concepts will be applied to actual situations by the use of tax return assignments. Focus is on individual considerations and planning. Prer., ACCT 3010 and ACCT 3020 with a grade of “C-” or above. Business students only. Meets with ACCT 6710. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Corporate and Partnership Taxation
description: Primary emphasis is on C and S corporations and partnerships. Basic analysis of planning and compliance of most forms of corporate and partnership organization, operations, mergers and dissolutions. Business planning. Issues related to state and local taxation may also be covered. Prer., ACCT 4210 with a grade of “C-” or higher. Business students only.

name: Introduction to Accounting Systems
description: An introduction to the elements in an accounting information system, one of an organization’s central information systems. Explores the newest technology and the accountant’s/financial analyst’s role in designing systems. Includes “Hands-on” projects designed to expose the student to various software tools commonly used by accountants and financial analysts. Prer., ACCT 3010 with a grade of “C-” or above; Business Students Only. Meets with ACCT 6730. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Accounting for Governments and Not-for-Profit Organizations
description: The course provides an introduction to financial reporting practices in governmental and not-for-profit organizations. Emphasis is placed on how financial reports created by governments and not-for-profit organizations are used by internal and external stakeholders. Accounting issues specific to governmental and not-for-profit organizations will also be covered in detail. Necessary for CPA exam preparation. Prer., ACCT 3010 and ACCT 3020 with a grade of “C-” or above. Meets with ACCT 6740. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Accounting Ethics and Institutions
description: An in-depth study of the technical and behavioral ethical standards existing for professional accountants in all fields, and of the political and regulatory institutions that affect the practice of professional accounting including the SEC, IRS, FASB, AICPA and state authorities. Prepares students for dealing successfully with ethical issues throughout their careers. Prer., ACCT 4600 with a grade of “C-” or above; Junior or Senior standing or COB Undergraduate Director permission. Meets with ACCT 6510.

name: Auditing
description: A study of generally accepted auditing standards. Specific focus is placed on concepts of the auditing function for financial audits, professional standards that guide audit performance, and processes and formal procedures used to plan, perform, and complete an audit. Prer., ACCT 3010 and ACCT 3020 with a grade of “C-” or above. Coreq., ACCT 4310. Business students only. Meets with ACCT 6600. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Advanced Auditing
description: Study of advanced theoretical and practical issues in auditing. Specific focus is placed on the application of auditing resources commonly used in practice. The course emphasizes case analysis, research, individual and team presentations, and classroom discussion. Prer., ACCT 4600 with a grade of “C-” or above. Business students only. Meets with ACCT 6620.

name: Topics in Accounting
description: Experimental course in accounting. Prer., Junior or senior standing or COB Undergraduate Director permission. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Internship in Accounting
description: Undergraduate accounting internship for business students. Prer., Junior/Senior business students only. Prer., ACCT 3010 with a grade of “B” or better. Consent required. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

name: Introduction to Accounting
description: MBA foundation course. Introduction to concepts, principles and practices used in preparation of financial statements for business enterprises, with emphasis on asset and liability recognition and measurement, income determination, and cash flow activities. Includes the use of spreadsheets. Prer., Graduate students only.

name: Financial Accounting Theory
description: This course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to analyze and evaluate financial accounting standard setting and financial accounting theory and concepts. The course also provides an opportunity for students to analyze and evaluate actual financial reporting treatments by public companies. The course emphasizes textbook chapter research and analysis, individual and team presentations, team projects and classroom discussion. Prer., ACCT 3010 and ACCT 3020 with a grade of “C-” or above, or equivalent coursework; MSA, MBA, or graduate Accounting Certificate students only.

name: Accounting for Decision Making
description: An exploration of the use of accounting information for executive decision-making. Emphasis is on understanding and applying basic managerial accounting skills to identify, use, and evaluate accounting information in both long-term strategic decisions and short-term operating decisions. Prer., Graduate students only  and ACCT 5500.

name: Advanced Managerial Accounting
description: Application of advanced managerial accounting information for planning, decision making and evaluation. Topics of current interest will be discussed and may include analysis of pricing, cost allocation, balanced scorecard and capital budgeting that relate to corporate decision making. This course includes learning through technical content, cases, creation and use of spreadsheets and current scholarly research articles in cost related topics. Prer., ACCT 3110 or ACCT 6100 with a grade of “C-” or better (or equivalent coursework). MSA, MBA, or graduate Accounting Certificate students only.

name: Accounting Ethics and Institutions
description: An in-depth study of the technical and behavioral ethical standards existing for professional accountants in all fields, and of the political and regulatory institutions that affect the practice of professional accounting including the SEC, IRS, FASB, AICPA and state authorities. Prepares students for dealing successfully with ethical issues throughout their careers. Prer., ACCT 4600 with a grade of “C-” or better or ACCT 6600; MSA, MBA, or graduate Accounting Certificate students only.

name: Auditing
description: A study of generally accepted auditing standards. Specific focus is placed on concepts of the auditing function for financial audits, professional standards that guide audit performance, and processes and formal procedures used to plan, perform, and complete an audit. Prer., ACCT 3010 and ACCT 3020 with a grade of “C-” or above; coreq., ACCT 4310 or ACCT 6730 or equivalent coursework; MSA, MBA, or graduate Accounting Certificate students only. Meets with ACCT 4600.

name: Advanced Auditing
description: Study of advanced theoretical and practical issues in auditing. Specific focus is placed on the application of auditing resources commonly used in practice. The course emphasizes case analysis, research, individual and team presentations, and classroom discussion. Prer., ACCT 4600 with a grade of “C-” or better or ACCT 6600; MSA, MBA, or graduate Accounting Certificate students only.

name: Individual Income Tax
description: Analysis of basic concepts of federal income taxes such as income, exclusions, deductions, and property transactions. Concepts will be applied to actual situations by the use of tax return assignments. Focus is on individual considerations and planning. Prer., ACCT 3010 and ACCT 3020 with a grade of “C-” or above, or equivalent coursework ; MSA, MBA, or graduate Accounting Certificate students only. Meets with ACCT 4210.

name: Corporate and Partnership Taxation
description: Primary emphasis is on C and S corporations and partnerships. Basic analysis of planning and compliance of most corporation and partnership organizations, operations, mergers and dissolutions. Business planning and international taxation also considered. Prer., ACCT 4210  with a grade of “C-” or better, or ACCT 6710, or equivalent coursework; MSA, MBA, or graduate Accounting Certificate students only. Meets with ACCT 4220.

name: Introduction to Accounting Systems
description: An introduction to the elements in an accounting information system. Explores the newest technology and the accountant’s/financial analyst’s role in designing systems. Includes exposure to various software tools commonly used by accountants and financial analysts. Prer., ACCT 3010 with a grade of “C-” or better, or equivalent coursework; MSA, MBA, or graduate Accounting Certificate students only. Meets with ACCT 4310.

name: Accounting for Governments and Not-for-Profit Organizations
description: The course provides an introduction to financial reporting practices in governmental and not-for-profit organizations. Emphasis is placed on how financial reports created by governments and not-for-profit organizations are used by internal and external stakeholders. Accounting issues specific to governmental and not-for-profit organizations will also be covered in detail. Prer., ACCT 3010 and ACCT 3020 with a grade of “C-” or above, or equivalent coursework; MSA, MBA, or graduate Accounting Certificate students only. Meets with ACCT 4410.

name: Advanced Financial Accounting
description: Provides an in-depth analysis into the theory and practices of accounting for business combinations, consolidated financial statements, and international operations. Prer., ACCT 3010 and ACCT 3020 with a grade of “C-” or above, or equivalent coursework; MSA, MBA, or graduate Accounting Certificate students only.

name: Federal Tax Research and Planning
description: Students learn methods of researching tax problems and gain experience through practical exercises in the uses of research tools in locating, understanding, and interpreting source materials. Using and applying tax research methods, students will learn basic tax planning concepts. Prer., ACCT 4220 with a grade of “C-” or better, or ACCT 6720, or equivalent coursework; MSA, MBA, or graduate Accounting Certificate students only.

name: Topics in Accounting - Graduate
description: Experimental course in accounting offered at the graduate level for the purpose of presenting new subject matter. Prer., Varies by Topic.

name: Internship in Accounting
description: Graduate internship in accounting. Prer., Instructor and Dean approval.

name: Independent Study in Accounting - Undergraduate
description: With the consent of the instructor who directs the study and the dean.

name: Independent Study in Accounting - Graduate
description: With the consent of the instructor who directs the study and the dean.

name: American Sign Language I
description: This is the first in a related series of courses that focus on the use and study of American Sign Language (ASL), the language that is widely used by Deaf Americans. This course includes basic ASL vocabulary, grammatical structures, and in-depth cultural awareness. Non-manual behavior, ASL structure, and fluency are included to challenge students’ ability to increase expressive and receptive skills in ASL. Students are introduced to the cultural values, beliefs, and behavioral norms shared by those within the Deaf community. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: American Sign Language II
description: This is the second in a related series of courses that focus on the use and study of American Sign Language (ASL), the language that is widely used by Deaf Americans. This course includes intermediate ASL vocabulary, grammatical structures, conversational behaviors, and in-depth cultural awareness. Non-manual behavior, ASL structure, and fluency are included to challenge students’ ability to increase expressive and receptive skills in ASL. Students are introduced to the cultural values, beliefs, and behavioral norms shared by those within the Deaf community. This course is designed for students who have completed a minimum of ASL I. Prer., ASL 1010. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: American Sign Language III
description: The third in a related series of courses that focus on the use and study of American Sign Language (ASL), the language that is widely used by Deaf Americans. This course continues to increase ASL vocabulary, grammatical structures, and in-depth cultural awareness. Non-manual behavior, ASL structure, and fluency are included to challenge students’ ability to increase expressive and receptive skills in ASL. An intermediate course designed for students who have completed a minimum of ASL I and ASL II. Prer., ASL 1010, ASL1020. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: American Sign Language IV
description: The fourth in a related series of courses that focus on the use and study of American Sign Language (ASL), the language that is widely used by Deaf Americans. This course provides the opportunity to develop and use stories and language activities in both receptive and expressive modes. Non-manual behavior, ASL structure, and fluency are included to challenge students’ ability to increase expressive and receptive skills in ASL. Offers a more in-depth discussion of the principles of ASL. Presents further exposure to more sophisticated dialogue. Prer., ASL 1010, ASL1020, ASL 2110. Course typically offered: Spring

name: American Sign Language Fingerspelling and Numbers
description: This course will aid students in developing increased fluency in their expressive and receptive abilities at ASL fingerspelling, one of the most difficult ASL skills to master, and aid in navigating the complex rules of ASL numbering. The course focuses on specific skills that underlie the fingerspelled word recognition process, and provides practice in correctly recognizing fingerspelled words and numbers in context. In addition to receptive skill development, students will hone their articulation and production of fingerspelling  and numbering. Taught in ASL. Prer., ASL 2120 or requisite experience.

name: American Sign Language V
description: This is the fifth in a related series of courses that focus on the use and study of American Sign Language (ASL), the language that is widely used by Deaf Americans. This course provides the opportunity to develop and use stories and language activities in both receptive and expressive modes. Non-manual behavior, ASL structure, and fluency are included to challenge students’ ability to increase expressive and receptive skills in ASL at an advanced level. It offers a more in-depth discussion of the principles of ASL and comparison of communication methodologies. Presents further exposure to more sophisticated dialogue. Prer., ASL 2120. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Introduction to American Sign Language Literature
description: Provides students with an opportunity to recognize the impact of Deaf Culture on emerging ASL literature. The course also covers non-fiction, poetry, and drama depicted in reading and videotapes related to everyday lives of deaf people. It develops insight and appreciation of deaf literature and its implications for deaf education. Original works will be studied, analyzed, and compared. An intermediate course for students who have completed a minimum of ASL I, II, and III. Prer., ASL 1010, ASL 1020, ASL 2110. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Internship in Applied American Sign Language
description: The Department of Languages and Cultures will offer to advanced language students the opportunity for supervised application of their knowledge in settings such as schools, social support agencies, etc. May be repeated up to three times for credit. Prer., Departmental permission.

name: Special Topics in American Sign Language and Culture
description: Varying topics of current importance in linguistic and socio-cultural study. May be repeated once for credit if the topic is different. Prer., ASL 2120 or equivalent.

name: Deaf Culture
description: Examines the culture of deaf people. The course will explore the customs, values, norms and heritage of the deaf community in America. Prer., ASL 1010 and ASL 1020. Meets with FCS 3590. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Contrastive Linguistic Analysis: ASL/English
description: Introduction to basic similarities and differences in the linguistic structures and uses of American Sign Language (ASL) and English. Examining categories from a universal perspective, contrastive linguistic analysis is accomplished by focusing on: phonological and morphological processes, syntactic properties, discourse types, word classes, and linguistic variation in Deaf and non-deaf communities in the United States. The student will also analyze both ASL and English language samples. Approved for LAS Cultural Diversity Requirement. Prer., Junior or Senior standing.

name: Contrastive Linguistic Analysis: ASL/English
description: Introduction to basic similarities and differences in the linguistic structures and uses of American Sign Language (ASL) and English. Examining categories from a universal perspective, contrastive linguistic analysis is accomplished by focusing on: phonological and morphological processes, syntactic properties, discourse types, word classes, and linguistic variation in Deaf and non-deaf communities in the United States. The student will also analyze both ASL and English language samples. Prer., Graduate students only.

name: Independent Study in American Sign Language
description: Independent work for advanced undergraduates only. By special arrangement with the faculty. Only for students presenting strong preparation in American Sign Language. May be repeated up to three times for credit. Prer., Consent of instructor.

name: Independent Study in American Sign Language
description: Independent work for advanced undergraduates only. By special arrangement with the faculty. Only for students presenting strong preparation in American Sign Language. May be repeated up to three times for credit. Prer., Consent of instructor.

name: Undergraduate Research - Independent Study
description: Provides an opportunity to conduct research with American Sign Language faculty and graduate students by one or more students on topics determined by a faculty member. Prer., Consent of instructor required.

name: Introduction to Archaeology
description: Covers the basic concepts and methodology of archaeology using archaeological case studies from around the world. Approved for LAS Social Science area requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Explore-Society, Health and Behavior; Inclusiveness (Global/Diversity); Sustainability. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

name: Introduction to Biological Anthropology
description: Evolution of humanity and its cultures. Covers primatology, evolution, race, biology, and prehistory. Approved for LAS Natural Science area requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Physical and Natural World. GT-SS3. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

name: Introduction to Cultural Anthropology
description: Introduction to the major aspects of culture, such as social organization, religion, economics, language, sustainability, diversity, and cultural change. Approved for LAS Social Science area and Global Awareness requirements. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Inclusiveness (Global/Diversity); Explore-Society, Health and Behavior; Sustainability. GT-SS3. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

name: Experimental Anthropology
description: Experimental anthropology features student-picked projects including, but not limited to: replication of lithic artifacts, processing of animal hides, ceramic reproductions, replications of indigenous foods, rock art reproductions, etc., using authentic methods. Requires weekend activities. Prer., ANTH 1020 or ANTH 1040.

name: Extraordinary Archaeology
description: This course introduces students to science-based archaeology by focusing on four or five extraordinary sites that have significantly changed the understanding of the past, and which can provide students with a feel for the range and scope of archaeological inquiry.

name: Introduction to Cognitive Archaeology
description: Course introduces students to the evolution and prehistory of the human mind through archaeological investigations of tools, hunting camps, living sites, cave paintings, engraved objects, figurines, ritualized burials, and personal ornamentation. Meets with INDS 2250, PSY 2250.

name: The Nature of Language
description: Introduction to the anthropological study of language. Approved for LAS Social Science area requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Society, Health and Behavior. GT-SS3. Prer., ANTH 1040 or sophomore standing. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Quantitative Methods in Anthropology
description: A survey of quantitative methods emphasizing the nature of hypothesis testing. Attention is given to special problems of bioanthropological, archaeological, and ethnographic data. Satisfies the LAS and Compass Curriculum Quantitative and Qualitative Reasoning requirement as a statistics course when taken by a student who has either 1) successfully completed MATH 1040 (or a mathematics course that has college algebra as a prerequisite), OR 2) scored 87% or higher on the College Algebra placement test and scored 50% or higher on the Business Calculus placement test. Prer., 9 completed hours in anthropology or consent of instructor. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Why Science Matters
description: Course discusses how science works and its role in the modern world. Each term the course will focus on three or four issues of importance (e.g., climate change, evolution, relativity, death) and examine how science enhances our ability to understand and engage these phenomena. Meets with PSY 3020.

name: Special Topics in Anthropology:
description: Examination of selected topics in anthropology in lecture or seminar format. Topics will change according to the interest of the instructor and students. Students may repeat the course for credit as long as the topic is different.

name: Anthropology of Art and Expressive Culture
description: This course introduces students to the anthropological study of art, aesthetics and expressive culture by considering several cross-cultural examples. Students will examine how aesthetics express and inform about the cultures in which they are found. Prer., ANTH 1020, ANTH 1030, ANTH 1040, or AH 1000.

name: Archaeology in the Public: Heritage Law, Ethics, and Community Engagement
description: Explores the role of government and public opinion in cultural resource legislation and ethics. Students will gain hands-on exposure to documenting and evaluating resource significance and will explore ethical considerations, descendant community engagement, cultural patrimony, and tribal rights. Prer., ANTH 1020.

name: Field Practicum in Applied Archaeology
description: A practicum course wherein students will work as part of a professional archaeological project and gain practical experience in archaeological field methods such as mapping, excavating, recording, survey, records and archives, field lab management, professional networking, and public consultation. Prer., ANTH 1020 and consent of instructor. Course typically offered: Summer

name: Special Topics in Archaeology
description: Intensive study of selected topics in archaeology. In different years deals with different topic areas. Prer., Varies depending on course topic. Sophomore standing or higher.

name: Lab Techniques in Archaeology
description: Provides hands-on experience cataloging and analyzing materials from archaeological sites. Topics will include analysis, computer applications, materials conservation, and artifact illustration, and also the methodological decision-making that affects how we describe, analyze, and interpret data. Prer., ANTH 1020 or consent of instructor. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Mapping Archaeology
description: We will use Geographic Information Systems (GIS) to produce maps of archaeological sites, view the archaeological record from new perspectives, reconstruct past landscapes, perform spatial analysis on artifacts, and ask spatial questions of past human behavior. Prer., ANTH 1020. Meets with GES 3215. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Archaeology of Native North America
description: The archaeology of North America, emphasizing the peopling of the Americas, indigenous histories, and colonization. Prer., ANTH 1020 or consent of instructor.

name: The Archaeology and Genetics of the Stone Age
description: The cultural evidence for human development from the earliest stone tool assemblages of the Plio-Pleistocene to the Mesolithic and Archaic cultures of the old and new worlds. Prer., ANTH 1020 or consent of instructor.

name: Native Peoples of the Southwest
description: Explore the archaeology, history, and culture of indigenous cultures of the U.S. Southwest including impacts of colonization, resistance, and resilience. Approved for LAS Cultural Diversity requirement. Prer., ANTH 1020, ANTH 1040, WEST 2010. Meets with WEST 3250.

name: Agricultural Origins and the Emergence of Urban Society
description: The evidence for the origins of agricultural economies and the emergence of complex social and political institutions in both the old and new worlds. Approved for LAS Social Science area requirement. Prer., ANTH 1020 or consent of instructor.

name: Archaeology of the Recent Past
description: History and practice of the sub-discipline of historical archaeology. Students will explore diverse perspectives in public archaeology, and critically examine individual case studies. Approved for LAS Social Science area requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Society, Health and Behavior. Prer., ANTH 1020 or consent of instructor.

name: Archaeological Approaches to Gender and Sexuality
description: Course covers archaeological approaches to diverse systems of gender and sexuality in past societies. Students will analyze various case studies, spanning periods from the Paleolithic to the recent past. Prer., ANTH 1020. Meets with WEST 3270. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Archaeology of Colorado
description: The ecological and geographical diversity of the State of Colorado has made it a rich source of archaeological research on its human past. This course covers the ways that archaeologists use material culture and landscape to study diverse cultural histories in the Centennial State. Prer., ANTH 1020.

name: Special Topics in Biological Anthropology
description: Intensive study of selected topics in biological anthropology. In different years deals with different topic areas. Prer., Sophomore standing or higher.

name: Human Reproduction: Dating, Mating, and Parenting
description: This course will examine various facets of human reproduction, including anatomy, neurology, hormones, biology, and parenting. The information in this course will be based on a cross-cultural, evolutionary understanding of human sexuality. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Explore-Society, Health and Behavior; Writing Intensive. Prer., ANTH 1030 or sufficient coursework in biology or health sciences. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Primatology
description: Behavior, ecology, and evolution of nonhuman primates. Emphasis on field studies, and on evolutionary explanations of social groups, mating systems, and behavior toward kin. Approved for LAS Natural Science area requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Physical and Natural World. Prer., ANTH 1030 or consent of instructor.

name: Hormones and Behavior
description: This course covers the topic of behavioral endocrinology. Students will learn about various hormones, the role of those hormones in humans, and to a lesser extent, non-human animals, and the role of hormones in the study of behavior. Prer., ANTH 1030 or sufficient coursework in Biology or Health Sciences.

name: Human Evolution
description: A detailed examination of the fossil evidence for human evolution, emphasizing functional analysis of human structure and the process of natural selection. Approved for LAS Natural Science area requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Explore-Physical and Natural World. Prer., ANTH 1030 or consent of instructor.

name: Forensic Anthropology
description: Explores the role of forensic anthropologists in crime scene investigation and mass disaster recovery. Students will learn to analyze skeletal remains to determine time since death, evaluate trauma, and identify age, sex, and ancestry. Prer., ANTH 1030 or instructor permission. Course typically offered: Alternative Even Years - Fall

name: Methods in Biological Anthropology
description: This course focuses on methods commonly used in the field of biological anthropology, exploring what it means to be human from the perspectives of our evolutionary history and our individual life Histories. Prer., ANTH 1030. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Human Biology and Ecology
description: The study of variation and adaptations of human populations in an ecological framework. Includes interactions between cultural and biological factors in health and in reproduction, and anthropological aspects of demography. Approved for LAS Natural Science area requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Physical and Natural World. Prer., ANTH 1030 or consent of instructor.

name: Humans on the Edge
description: This course uses a biocultural approach to explore the resilience of the human species looking at the ways that humans adapt biologically, physiologically, behaviorally, and culturally to survive and thrive in extreme environments and situations where few other animals can. Prer., Sophomore standing or above or ANTH 1030 or instructor consent.

name: Evolutionary Medicine and Health
description: This course provides an evolutionary lens on human health. We explore data from biology, osteology, primatology, and cross-cultural studies to gain a holistic understanding of modem medicine and health. Topics include reproduction, cancers, aging, nutrition and energetics, and adaptive immunity. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Inclusiveness (Global/Diversity); Navigate. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Bioarchaeology
description: Bioarchaeology focuses on the study of human remains from archaeological sites, both ancient and historic. In this class, we will learn the bones of the human skeleton, look at how health and behavior can be interpreted from human skeletal remains and explore case studies from around the world. Prer., Sophomore standing or ANTH 1020 or ANTH 1030 or instructor consent.

name: Cultural Diversity in the United States
description: Examines the construction of diversity and perceptions of difference in the United States from a variety of perspectives. Provides students an opportunity to create a public-facing local research project. Approved for LAS Cultural Diversity requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Inclusiveness. Prer., Second-year student status or above; ANTH 1040 or permission of instructor. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Anthropological Approaches to Globalization
description: Through specific case studies, seminar analyzes how cultural identities and societal changes both respond to and shape global agendas. Addresses innovative anthropological and ethnographic approaches to globalization studies, and considers why they form a critical component of contemporary anthropological research. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Explore-Society, Health and Behavior; Inclusiveness (Global/Diversity); Sustainability; Writing Intensive. Prer., Second-year student status; ANTH 1040 or permission of instructor. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Anthropological Approaches to Race
description: How has anthropology engaged with, produced knowledge about, and understood social conceptions of race and racism? Taught across the four sub-fields of anthropology, this course emphasizes disciplinary methods to track current directions in the study of race and racism. Approved for LAS Social Science area and Global Awareness requirements. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Navigate; Writing Intensive. Prer., Sophomore standing or consent of instructor.

name: Christianity and Freedom
description: This course is an ethnographic approach to analyzing how Christianity shapes and is shaped by questions of freedom. Students will read, compare, and critique scholarly accounts of Christianity both in the US and abroad. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Arts, Humanities, and Cultures.

name: Environmental Anthropology
description: This course serves as an overview of the subfield of environmental anthropology. It explores anthropological approaches to understanding the relationship between humans and the environment. Prer., ANTH 1040.

name: Ethnographic Methods and Theory
description: Theoretical, case-oriented introduction to ethnographic research. Practical training provided in basic ethnographic research and analytical methods. Designed to engage students in grounded ethnographic research in the local setting. Research students design, conduct, analyze, and present as members of a team. Prer., ANTH 1040 and either ANTH 2800 or other cultural anthropology course. Course typically offered: Fall

name: History and Practice of Archaeology
description: This course only offered in spring. A seminar designed for students who already have some archaeology coursework and are interested in the history and development of the discipline as well as trowel’s edge methodologies and theoretical debates. Prer., ANTH 1020. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Applied Community Studies
description: A service-learning, community-based research course in which students, professors, and community members work together to reach community-identified goals. Working in teams, students will learn to apply anthropology and human geography research methods in developing effective community outreach programs. Prer., two courses in anthropology, sociology, geography, or education, or permission of instructor. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Special Topics in Cultural Anthropology
description: Intensive study of selected topics in cultural anthropology. In different years deals with different topic areas. Prer., Sophomore standing or higher.

name: Special Topics in Linguistic Anthropology
description: Intensive study of selected topics in linguistic anthropology. In different years deals with different topic areas. Prer., Sophomore standing or higher.

name: Language, Culture, and Society
description: An examination of the social and cultural functions of language, emphasizing the use of linguistic and cultural methods and theories in anthropology. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Writing Intensive. Prer., Sophomore standing. ANTH 2800 or permission of instructor. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Native American Languages and Cultures
description: Examines Native American languages focusing on their cultural value in traditional/historic and contemporary contexts. Students study comparative linguistic typology of Native American languages, endangerment and revitalization efforts, and explore relations among Native American languages, cultures, nations, and bilingual needs. Approved for LAS Cultural Diversity requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Inclusiveness (Global/Diversity). Prer., ANTH 2800 or ANTH 3420 or WEST 3420 or WEST 2010. Meets with WEST 3820.

name: Language and Discrimination
description: Language practices and ideologies continually (re)produce forms of social difference and inequality within and across communities of interaction. This course examines the ways the semiotic landscape is intrinsically linked with political and economic structures and processes that aid in the establishment and perpetuation of language commodification and social differences. Throughout the course we will identify how racial inequalities are continually perpetuated in language use and practices. We will also explore how language can aid in the dismantling of social injustices.

name: History and Theory of Anthropology
description: This course is only offered in fall. History of the growth of anthropology and the questions it asks from the mid-1800s to present day. Prer., ANTH 1040 or consent of instructor. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Hunter-Gatherer Societies: Past and Present
description: In this course, we investigate the nature of hunter-gatherer societies from the archaeological and ethnographic points of view. Hunting and gathering was the only way of life for most of our past and this profoundly shaped our biological and cultural development. Approved for LAS Global Awareness requirement. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Advanced Topics in Archaeology
description: Intensive study of selected topics in archaeology and prehistory. Prer., Vary depending on course topic.  Meets with ANTH 5200.

name: Wild Cognition
description: After appropriate academic and skills training, qualified students will spend several days in the wilderness using prehistoric techniques of hunting and gathering. At the same time they will be engaged in testing specific hypotheses concerning the cognitive challenges involved in these activities.

name: Advanced Laboratory Techniques in Archaeology
description: In this laboratory practicum, students analyze and interpret archaeological data and materials from the field school. Students will engage in specialized analysis techniques, data management and interpretation, report writing, and curatorial activities related to archaeological materials. Prer., ANTH 3179/3190 and ANTH 3210.

name: Landscape Archaeology: Sustainability and Collapse
description: Explore human landscapes at scales of research beyond the “site.” Survey perspectives from historically capitalist and pre-capitalist perspectives. Sustainability is the thread that ties this course together. Archaeology at regional scales explores environmental justice, ecology, and heritage. Approved for LAS Global Awareness and Social Sciences requirements. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Explore-Society, Health and Behavior; Sustainability. Prer., ANTH 1020. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Advanced Topics in Biological Anthropology
description: Intensive study of selected issues in human evolution, human biology, and primate behavior and ecology. Different years deal with different topic areas. Prer., ANTH 1030 or consent of instructor.

name: Cognitive Evolution
description: Examines the evolution of primate and hominid cognition. Content includes basic neuroanatomy, relevant evolutionary theory, and neuropsychology (brain damage patterns), but the emphasis will be placed on the primate comparative evidence, paleoneurology (fossil endocasts), and the archaeological record. Open to Juniors and Seniors only. Meets with ANTH 5310. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Field Methods in Biological Anthropology
description: The purpose of this field course is to gain hands-on experience of a biological anthropology project in an international setting. The field of anthropology  has aimed to study humans from a cross-cultural, holistic perspective. International field work provides students with a first-hand experience of anthropological field work. Prer., ANTH 1030 or sufficient coursework in anthropology.

name: Parasites in Human Evolution
description: What do sexual reproduction, immunity, and disgust have in common? PARASITES. Evolutionarily, our species has been in contact with microscopic animals that use us for shelter and food. How did this relationship evolve? Can we truly be healthy without them? Prer., ANTH 1030 or Instructor Permission. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Physical and Natural World. Course typically offered: Alternative Odd Years - Spring

name: Primate Behavior and Ecology Methods
description: The course is designed to give students a working knowledge of primate behavioral ecology in a zoological environment. The objective of the course is to give students experience in major methodological aspects of primate behavior, data collection, exploratory, and confirmatory data analyses. This course will include an introduction to relevant statistical techniques. Prer., ANTH 1030 recommended. Course typically offered: Summer

name: Advanced Topics in Cultural Anthropology
description: Intensive study of selected topics in cultural anthropology. In different years deals with different topic areas. Prer., Vary depending on course topic. Meets with WEST 4400.

name: Museums and Meaning
description: Students will critically evaluate the ways in which anthropology museums make meaning through practice. We scrutinize how museums can (mis)represent culture. We will focus specifically on issues of voice, narrative building, representation, authority, decolonization, and sensitivity. Approved for LAS Cultural Diversity requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Inclusiveness (Global/Diversity); Writing Intensive. Prer., ANTH 1040 or MSGP 2000. Course typically offered: Alternative Even Years - Fall

name: Labor & Social Transformation
description: This course is an advanced exploration into the theoretical and ethical dimensions of labor. It compares and contrasts categories of “labor” in order to highlight both the history of what labor is and the future of what creative attention to labor might enable in political and social spheres. Approved for LAS Social Science area and Global Awareness requirements.

name: Food and Empire
description: This course considered the people, process, and relationships whereby food serves as a channel for the exertion of power-linking moments of war, colonialism, and imperialism to the development of the American industrial food system. Approved for LAS Cultural Diversity and LAS Social Science area requirements.  Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Inclusiveness.

name: Ethnography of Sport
description: The course is designed to enhance student understanding of sport from an ethnographic perspective. The course introduces socio-cultural anthropological field methods including participant observation, interviewing, and narrative techniques and analysis of qualitative data. Prer., ANTH 1040 or permission of instructor. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: The Archaeology of Numbers
description: This course examines numbers as systems comprised of interacting psychological, behavioral, and material domains, using concepts and evidence from psychology and ethnography to interpret the archaeological record. Course content includes the neuropsychology of numeracy, ethnographic behaviors with numbers, and ancient and modern numbers and counting devices. Meets with ANTH 5515.

name: Evolutionary Neuropsychology
description: This course serves as an introduction to the evolution of the structures and the functions of the human brain. Prer., PSY 2110 or instructor consent. Meets with PSY 4650.

name: Internship in Anthropology
description: A program of study and learning outside the classroom. Practical exposure to field of interest is intended to provide appropriate experience related to a student’s career orientation. Students must have departmental permission. Anthropology majors only. Prerequisites vary depending on area of specialization.

name: Advanced Topics in Linguistic Anthropology
description: Intensive study of selected topics in anthropological linguistics. In different years deals with different topic areas. Prer., Consent of instructor.

name: Senior Seminar in Anthropology
description: This course offered only in spring.  A one semester special topics course designed to provide a synthesizing cap to the student’s undergraduate program in anthropology. Topics vary by semester. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Summit. Prer., ANTH 3970. Senior status. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Honors Thesis
description: For honors in Anthropology. a one semester research project. The student will write a formal research paper drawing on primary sources and pertinent secondary material. The student will work under the direction of a full time member of the department and will have a second member as an additional reader. The student will prepare an oral presentation to the faculty to include a thesis defense and responses to general questions in the four sub-fields. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Summit. Prer., Senior status and consent of department chair.

name: Advanced Topics in Archaeology
description: Intensive study of selected topics in archaeology and prehistory.  Meets with ANTH 4200.

name: Cognitive Evolution
description: Examines the evolution of primate and hominid cognition. Content includes basic neuroanatomy, evolutionary theory, and neuropsychology, but the emphasis will be placed on the primate comparative evidence, paleoneurology (fossil endocasts), and the archaeological record. Prer., Graduate students only. Meets with ANTH 4310.

name: The Archaeology of Numbers
description: This course examines numbers as systems comprised of interacting psychological, behavioral, and material domains, using concepts and evidence from psychology and ethnography to interpret the archaeological record. Course content includes the neuropsychology of numeracy, ethnographic behaviors with numbers, and ancient and modern numbers and counting devices. Meets with ANTH 4515.

name: Advanced Topics in Anthropological Linguistics: Graduate Level
description: Intensive study of selected topics in anthropological linguistics (e.g., morphological and syntactic typology, comparative phonetics/phonology, linguistic field methods, narrative analysis); in different semesters one specific topic will be addressed. Graduate level only. Prer., ANTH 2800 or equivalent; Permission of instructor.

name: Project Management for Cultural Heritage and Environmental Resource Stewardship
description: This course covers project management essentials for cultural heritage and environmental resource sectors. Students will learn planning, team coordination, and strategies for stakeholder engagement, ethical concerns, and regulatory compliance to address cultural heritage and environmental science challenges.

name: Masters Thesis
description: Masters Thesis

name: Independent Study in Anthropology
description: Hours and credits to be arranged. Consent of instructor is required.

name: Independent Study - Research and Creative Works
description: Provides an opportunity to conduct research with Anthropology faculty by one or more students on topics determined by a faculty member. Prer., Consent of instructor required.

name: Independent Study in Anthropology
description: Prer., Consent of instructor.

name: Candidate for Degree
description: Candidate for Degree

name: Beginning Arabic I
description: This course begins a sequence dealing with the development of functional proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing the Arabic language. The course is conducted in Arabic. Emphasis is on communication in the language. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Beginning Arabic II
description: The second course begins a sequence dealing with the development of functional proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing the Arabic language. The course is conducted in Arabic. Emphasis is on communication in the language. Prer., ARBC 1010 or equivalent.

name: Intermediate Arabic I
description: This course begins an intermediate level sequence dealing with the development of functional proficiency in listening, speaking, reading and writing the Arabic language. Conducted in Arabic with emphasis on communication.

name: Art Through the Ages
description: An introduction to the history of art and visual culture from around the world from prehistory to c. 1400. Course reading, writing assignments, and field trips (for in-person classes) equip students with the tools they need to think critically, write effectively, and build confidence in discussing art and culture outside the classroom. Approved for LAS Humanities area requirement.  Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Inclusiveness; Explore - Arts, Humanities, and Cultures. GT-AH1.

name: Global Visual Culture: 1300 to the Present
description: An introduction to the history of art and visual culture from c. 1300 to the present. Course reading, writing assignments, and field trips (for in-person classes) equip students with the tools they need to think critically, write effectively, and build confidence in discussing art outside the classroom. Approved for LAS Humanities area requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Inclusiveness; Explore - Arts, Humanities, and Cultures.

name: Introduction to Visual Culture
description: An introduction to the key issues in visual cultural studies through a broad examination of historical shifts in art and popular culture across time periods and geographies. Through course readings, writing assignments, and field trips (for in-person classes) students learn to effectively apply visual analysis and media literacy skills to interpret diverse forms of cultural expression, building confidence in discussing the politics of visuality and forms of representation from the development of perspective in the Renaissance; to photography and film; to video games and virtual reality in the digital age. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Explore-Arts, Humanities, and Cultures; Writing Intensive. GT-AH1.

name: Survey: Special Topics
description: Selected topics focused on various historic periods of art history from throughout the world’s cultures. May be repeated for credit if the topic is different.

name: Survey: Ancient Art
description: A survey of sculpture, painting, and architecture from the Paleolithic through the Roman periods. The arts of Mesopotamia, Egypt, Anatolia, Greece, and Rome will be given primary consideration. Approved for LAS Humanities area requirement. GT-AH1.

name: Survey: Medieval Art
description: A survey of the arts of early Christian, Byzantine, early Medieval, Romanesque, and Gothic periods. Approved for LAS Humanities area requirement. GT-AH1.

name: Survey: Renaissance
description: Survey of the arts of Europe, c. 1400-1600, covering the Early Renaissance through Mannerist stylistic periods. Students study artists such as Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, and Sofonisba Anguissola. This course will also look beyond the confines of Europe to consider global connections, appropriations, and artistic influence during the “age of exploration.” Approved for LAS Humanities area requirement. GT-AH1. Prer., One AH 1000 level course or instructor permission.

name: Survey: Art of the Americas
description: This course covers diverse topics in arts of the Americas. Specific course topics will change, ranging in time from pre-colonial to contemporary art, or surveying of the arts of North America, Mesoamerica and/or South America. Prer., One AH 1000 level course or instructor permission.

name: Survey: Modern Art
description: An introduction to major movements in art and architecture from the late 19th to the mid-20th century. Art from Europe and the United States will be given primary consideration, beginning with Post-Impressionism and ending with Abstract Expressionism. Approved for LAS Humanities area requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Arts, Humanities, and Cultures. GT-AH1.

name: Survey: Pop Art to the Present
description: An introduction to major movements in art and visual culture across the world from the mid-twentieth century to the present, beginning with Pop Art and ending with a survey of contemporary trends. Prer., One AH 1000 level course or instructor permission.

name: Survey: Eighteenth-Century Art
description: Survey of eighteenth-century European painting, sculpture, and architecture. Students explore the careers of painters including Antoine Watteau, William Hogarth, and Elisabeth Louise Vigee Le Brun as well as topics including Rococo and Neoclassical aesthetics, the Enlightenment, the Grand Tour, race, gender, and the art of revolutions. Approved for LAS Humanities area requirement. GT-AH1. Prer., One AH 1000 level course or instructor permission.

name: Topics in Art History
description: Emphasizes study of a more specific area than that covered in regular art history course offerings. For further information see individual course listing for each semester.

name: History of Photography
description: The history of photography from its infancy to the present. The development of the photograph as art will be traced from the early 19th-century pioneers through the contemporary masters.

name: The Life and Works of Yoko Ono
description: This course examines the life and works of artist Yoko Ono through social, political, and historical contexts to gain insight on her art and music. Her biography, art theory and criticism published about her works, as well as creative and collaborative assignments will be explored. Approved for LAS Cultural Diversity requirement. Meets with JPNS 3210.

name: The Art of Greece and Rome
description: A consideration of the culture of ancient Greece and Rome as expressed by architecture, painting, and sculpture from around 800 B.C. to 400 A.D. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Writing Intensive.

name: Women, Visual Arts, and Culture I
description: A survey of the lives and contributions of women artists, from the Renaissance to c. 1900. The primary objectives are to introduce issues of gender in the production of visual culture and familiarize the student with the critical literature of art history. Prer., permission of instructor. Approved for LAS Cultural Diversity requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Writing Intensive. Meets with WEST 3160.

name: Women, Visual Arts, and Culture II
description: Introduction to feminist theory and women’s artistic production from 1970 to the present. Focuses on how women’s art attempts to resist normative ideals of femininity, subvert aesthetic hierarchies, and illuminates the intersections of race, gender, and sexual orientation. Prer., AH 2000 or permission of instructor. Meets with WEST 3260.

name: From Modern to Postmodern Art
description: This course will examine the rapid change that characterized the art of the 20th and 21st centuries. We will begin with the emergence of cubism, dadaism, and surrealism in Europe, then shifting to American innovations, from Abstract Expressionism to graffiti.

name: Introduction to Feminist Film, Video and Digital Media
description: A survey of major themes in feminist independent film, video and web-based projects produced since the mid-1970s. Meets with WEST 3180.

name: Film, Video and the Avant-Garde
description: An examination of the relationship between avant-garde film and video, and the history of modern and contemporary art. Meets with FILM 3330.

name: African American Art
description: Introduction to contemporary (1970-) African American art forms with inclusion of traditional African art’s influence on American Black culture. Approved for LAS Humanities area and Cultural Diversity requirements.

name: Art of Japan
description: Examines the depth of Japanese aesthetics through layers of art and experience. In addition to sculpture, painting and ceramics, class material encompasses the artistry of the Tea ceremony, theatre (e.g., Kabuki, No & Butoh), calligraphy and textiles. Approved for Global Awareness requirement.

name: Islamic Arts
description: Investigates the essence and diversity of Islamic culture through time and space as it is visually expressed in architecture and other arts. Approved for LAS Global Awareness requirement. Prer., ANTH 1500, a course in Medieval art, Medieval history or by permission of instructor.

name: Romanesque and Gothic Art
description: A consideration of Romanesque and Gothic culture as manifest in the sculpture, painting, and architecture of Europe from around 1030-1350.

name: Baroque Art
description: The 17th century throughout Europe with primary attention to Caravaggio, Rubens, Bernini, Poussin, Velasquez, and Rembrandt.

name: Topics in American Art
description: Selected topics in the art of America from colonial period to the present, including folk art, craft, modern art, post-modern architecture, monuments, popular art and culture, etc. Prer., A H 1000 or A H 2000 level survey.

name: Contemporary Art
description: An in-depth, thematic study of art of the 1990s to the present that emphasizes the analysis of the art of our time in relation to a variety of critical texts. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Writing Intensive. Prer., A H 1000, or 2000 level survey.

name: Folk Arts, Folk Expressions, and Folkscapes
description: This course investigates different cultural expressions from belief systems to folk performances, vernacular architecture, and yard art where ingenuity creates senses of place, action, and performance. Includes visits to collections and folk art sites plus folk craft workshops. Meets with VAPA 3920. Prer., VAPA 1020, VAPA 1050, VAPA 1100.

name: Art History: Theories and Methods
description: This course will explore the history of art history as a discipline through an overview of common theoretical perspectives, methodologies and problems. In it, students will become acquainted with the theoretical and critical issues that currently dominate art historical scholarship and better understand the stakes of this field of study today. Prer., AH 1500.

name: Seminar: The Practice of Art History
description: Seminar experience in art history methodology. Required of all graduating majors. Open to students with 15 hours of upper-division coursework in art history.

name: Internship in Art History
description: Supervised opportunities for advanced art history students to apply their knowledge and obtain experience in a variety of professional arenas. Prer., Permission of advisor.

name: Meso-American Art and Architecture: Sacred Time and Space
description: Examines art traditions, cultural practices and the ethno-aesthetics of the Meso-American societies, Olmec, Maya and Aztec, in light of their history and subsequent European colonization. Different art forms are studied to understand the interdependency of art, ceremony, religious and royal display, cultural continuities, tradition and change. Approved for LAS Global Awareness requirement. Prer., AH 1000, AH 1500, or consent of instructor. Meets with WEST 4450.

name: Art and Ritual of the South Pacific
description: Investigates myriad art traditions and cultural practices of Polynesia, Melanesia, and Micronesia. Students learn to critique and analyze dynamics of power, cultural continuities and change. Examines ways art acts as a vehicle or catalyst for socio-political concerns. Approved for Global Awareness requirement. Meets with VAPA 4470.

name: Art of the Italian Renaissance I
description: A study of major trends in the development of painting, sculpture, and architecture as they reflect the culture of Renaissance Italy from around 1300-1500. Prer., AH 2820 or equivalent.

name: Art of the Italian Renaissance II
description: The late Renaissance and mannerism. The art of 16th-century Italy; special emphasis upon Michelangelo, Titian and Venice, both Florentine and Roman Mannerists, with some attention to Caravaggio. Prer., AH 2820 or equivalent.

name: Northern Renaissance Art
description: History of painting in northern Europe from the late 14th through the 16th century with primary emphasis on the art of the Low Countries. Prer., A H 2820 or equivalent.

name: Nineteenth Century Art I
description: History of the neoclassic and Romantic movements in European art with special reference to the Painting of David, Goya, Ingres, Gericault, and Delacroix, as well as consideration of architecture and sculpture from 1780 to 1850.

name: Nineteenth Century Art II
description: A study of the developments of Realism, Impressionism, Post-Impressionism, and Symbolism in France and England from 1850 to 1905.

name: Modern Art: 1900-1945
description: An in-depth, thematic study of the history of the avant-garde between 1890 and 1945 that emphasizes thee analysis of art of this period in relation to a variety of critical texts.

name: Art since 1945
description: An in-depth, thematic study of Modernism and Post- Modernism in the visual arts that emphasizes the analysis of art and architecture of this period in relation to a variety of critical texts. Prer., AH 2000 level survey.

name: Senior Capstone in Art History
description: This Senior Seminar is a requirement for graduation in the Art History concentration of VAPA. It is only offered in the Spring Semester and it is open to seniors and juniors. The senior seminar, or capstone, is a rigorous and demanding research course devoted to the development of your senior thesis. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Summit; Writing Intensive. Prer., AH 1500 and junior or senior standing. Meets with FILM 4980.

name: Independent Study in Art History
description: Independent Study in Art History on the undergraduate level with any full-time professor by arrangement.

name: Independent Study - Research and Creative Works
description: Provides an opportunity to conduct research with faculty by one or more students on topics determined by a faculty member. Prer., Consent of instructor required.

name: Astronomy of the Solar System
description: The methods and results of modern astronomy (solar systems and stars) at an elementary level. Approved for LAS Natural Science area requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Physical and Natural World. GT-SC2.

name: Astronomy of the Universe
description: The methods and results of modern astronomy (solar systems, stars, galaxies, black holes, quasars, cosmology) at an elementary level. Approved for LAS Natural Science area requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Physical and Natural World. GT-SC2.

name: Foundations of Athletic Training
description: For students pursuing athletic training as a career. Foundational concepts for athletic trainers in prevention, recognition, and management of sport-related injuries and conditions. Also includes introduction to risk management and legal issues. Prer., HPNU 3050, HPNU 3060 (formerly BIOL 3050/3060 or BIOL 4350 or BIOL 2010/2020).

name: Foundations in Athletic Training II
description: This course will provide the fundamental knowledge in injury diagnosis, management, treatment, and rehabilitation for athletic trainers. Includes healthcare delivery concepts, epidemiology, interprofessional practice, environmental conditions, patient education, athletic training room management, and documentation/EMR concepts. Prer., Admission to the MSAT program. Coreq., ATRN 5051.

name: Injury Diagnosis and Management I
description: In-depth investigation of assessment, treatment, and rehabilitation of musculoskeletal injury of the lower extremity. Prer., Admission to the MSAT program. Coreq., ATRN 5051.

name: Injury Diagnosis and Management II
description: In-depth investigation of assessment, treatment, and rehabilitation of injury of the spine, thorax, and head. Prer., ATRN 5011, ATRN 5051. Coreq., ATRN 5052.

name: Injury Diagnosis and Management III
description: In-depth investigation of assessment, treatment, and rehabilitation of musculoskeletal injury of the upper extremity. Prer., ATRN 5012, ATRN 5052. Coreq., ATRN 6053.

name: Manual Therapy I
description: Introduction to the theory, skills, and clinical use of manual therapy in sport. Techniques introduced will include joint mobilization, muscle energy, proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation, massage, myofascial release, instrument assisted soft tissue mobilization, and myofascial decompression. Prer., ATRN 5011.

name: Basic Athletic Training Skills
description: Introduction to the foundational skills of athletic training, including emergency care, wound care, taping, wrapping, and bracing. Prer., Admission to the MSAT program, CPR Certification.

name: Athletic Training Lab I
description: Introduces hands-on practice of and clinical decision making in prevention, diagnosis, treatment, rehabilitation, and return to play skills. Application to the lower extremity. Prer., Admission to the MSAT program. Coreq., ATRN 5000, ATRN 5011.

name: Athletic Training Lab II
description: Introduces hands-on practice of and clinical decision making in prevention, diagnosis, treatment, rehabilitation, and return to play skills of the torso and head. Also includes basic manual therapy skills. Prer., ATRN 5051. Coreq., ATRN 5012, ATRN 5015.

name: Athletic Training Clinical Education I
description: Integrated clinical education experiences under the supervision of preceptors in healthcare settings on and off campus. Opportunities for demonstration of level-specific skills, clinical decision making, and professional behavior. First in a four-course series. Prer., Admission to the MSAT program. Coreq., ATRN 5011, ATRN 5051

name: Athletic Training Clinical Education II
description: Integrated clinical education experiences under the supervision of preceptors in healthcare settings on and off campus. Opportunities for demonstration of level-specific skills, clinical decision making, and professional behavior. Second in a four-course series. Prer., ATRN 5051, ATRN 5061. Coreq., ATRN 5012, ATRN 5052.

name: Pharmacology and General Medical Conditions
description: Assessment and management of general medical conditions and pharmacological principles for physically active populations. Hands-on practice and clinical decision-making in prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and return to play skills for general medical conditions, sudden-death situations, & pharmacology.  Prer., ATRN 5012, ATRN 5052. Coreq., ATRN 5013.

name: Manual Therapy II
description: Introduction of laboratory skills of manual therapy in sport. Techniques introduced will include joint mobilization, muscle energy, proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation, massage, myofascial release, instrument assisted soft tissue mobilization, and myofascial decompression. Prer., ATRN 5051. Coreq., ATRN 5015.

name: Athletic Training Lab III
description: Introduces hands-on practice of and clinical decision making in prevention, diagnosis, treatment, rehabilitation, and return to play skills of the upper extremity. Prer., ATRN 5012, ATRN 5052. Coreq., ATRN 5013.

name: Athletic Training Clinical Education III
description: Integrated clinical education experiences under the supervision of preceptors in healthcare settings on and off campus. Opportunities for demonstration of level-specific skills, clinical decision making, and professional behavior. Third in a four-course series. Prer., ATRN 5052, ATRN 5062. Coreq., ATRN 5013, ATRN 6010, ATRN 6053.

name: Athletic Training Clinical Education IV
description: Integrated clinical education experiences under the supervision of preceptors in healthcare settings on or off-campus. Immersive experiences for demonstration of entry-level mastery of athletic training knowledge, skills and abilities, clinical decision making, and professional behavior. Final in a four-course series. Prer., ATRN 6053, ATRN 6063.

name: Graduate Research Project
description: Allows students to develop advanced skills and knowledge of the research process. Students will complete an applied research project under the guidance of faculty. Prer., HPNU 5010.

name: Introduction to Library Research
description: Introduction to the use of library services and research materials. Emphasis on the individual research needs. Designed for the undergraduate student in any discipline.

name: Biology in the Modern World
description: Designed for the nonmajor. The introductory principles of biology stressing the relationships between man and the environment. Concepts include heredity, evolution, genetics, nutrition, physiology, and ecology. Satisfies the LAS natural science requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Physical and Natural World. GT-SC2. To be taken with BIOL 1060 to satisfy the LAS laboratory requirement. May not count as credit for the major. Fall, Spring. GT-SC2.

name: Project Lead The Way - Biomedical Sciences
description: Students explore concepts of biology and medicine to determine factors that led to the death of a fictional person. Students design their own experiments to solve problems of human physiology, biology, and medicine.

name: Project Lead The Way - Human Body Systems
description: Students examine interactions among human body systems that result in muscle movement, reflex, and voluntary action and respiration. Students build organs and tissues on a skeletal manikin.

name: Project Lead The Way - Medical Interventions
description: Students learn and explore methods that prevent, diagnose, and treat diseases, including those that detect and fight infections, evaluate DNA sequence data, and evaluate cancer treatment options.

name: Introductory Biology Laboratory
description: May be taken in conjunction with BIOL 1000 to satisfy the LAS science requirement and lab requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Physical and Natural World. GT-SC1.

name: General Biology: Organismic Biology
description: The lecture component of an integrated lecture-laboratory course that presents the diversity of prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms emphasizing structure, function, ecology, and evolution. Students must also register for the laboratory, BIOL 1310. Prer., High school biology and chemistry, or consent of instructor. GT-SC2. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: General Biology: Organismic Biology Laboratory
description: The laboratory component of an integrated lecture-laboratory course that presents the diversity of prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms emphasizing structure, function, ecology, and evolution. Students must also register for the lecture, BIOL 1300. Prer., High school biology and chemistry, or consent of instructor. GT-SC1. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: General Biology: Introduction to the Cell
description: The lecture component of an integrated lecture-laboratory course that introduces concepts of the structure/function relationships among biological molecules, of cellular metabolism, and of genetics and molecular biology. Students must also register for the laboratory, BIOL 1360. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Physical and Natural World. GT-SC2. Prer., CHEM 1401 or CHEM 1001 or CHEM 1201, and BIOL 1300/1310, or consent of instructor. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: General Biology: Introduction to the Cell Laboratory
description: The laboratory component of an integrated lecture-laboratory course that introduces concepts of the structure/function relationships among biological molecules, of cellular metabolism, and of genetics and molecular biology. Students must also register for the lecture, BIOL 1350. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Physical and Natural World. GT-SC1. Prer., CHEM 1401 or CHEM 1001, and BIOL 1300/1310, or consent of instructor. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Microbiology
description: Presentation of the basic aspects of microbiology within a broad biological perspective. Subject matter will include microbiological concepts and methodology; a survey of the distinguishing properties of microorganisms based on structural-functional relationships: introduction to growth, metabolism, genetics, and ecology. Fall. Spring. MUST ALSO REGISTER FOR BIOL 2130 – MICROBIOLOGY LAB. Prer., BIOL 1300/1310 and BIOL 1350/1360 or HPNU 2010 or HPNU 3050; CHEM 1201 or CHEM 1401/1402 or CHEM 1221.

name: Project Lead The Way - Biomedical Innovation
description: Students build on the knowledge and skills gained from the three previous PLTW courses to design innovative solutions for pressing health challenges of the 21st century. Prer.; BIOL 1010, BIOL 1011, and BIOL 1013.

name: Microbiology Laboratory
description: MUST BE TAKEN IN CONJUNCTION WITH BIOL 2030. A series of laboratory experiments designed to illustrate the basic concepts of microbiology with hands-on experience. Fall, Spring. Prer., BIOL 1300/1310 and BIOL 1350/1360 or HPNU 2010 or HPNU 3050; CHEM 1201 or CHEM 1401/1402 or CHEM 1221.

name: Biostatistics
description: An introduction to the principles, concepts, and processes involved in scientific research, with emphasis in biology. This includes study design, basic data analyses, data interpretation and evaluation of the scientific literature. Satisfies the LAS and Compass Curriculum Quantitative and Qualitative Reasoning requirement as a statistics course when taken by a student who has either 1) successfully completed MATH 1040 (or a mathematics course that has college algebra as a prerequisite), OR 2) scored 87% or higher on the College Algebra placement test and scored 50% or higher on the Business Calculus placement test. Prer., BIOL 3830 and MATH 1350 or consent of instructor.  Meets with BIOL 5020. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Cell Biology
description: Study of the structural and functional aspects of cellular life with emphasis on biological macromolecules, organelles, membranes, and cellular processes including respiration, photosynthesis, mitotic division and signal transduction. Prer., BIOL 3830. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Microbiology: Bacteriology/Mycology
description: Bacteriology/Mycology is an upper division, advanced study of the metabolism, physiology, and genetics of bacteria, yeast and fungus. Prer., BIOL 3020.

name: Bacteriology/Mycology Laboratory
description: Laboratory course to accompany BIOL 3100. Prer., BIOL 3100 concurrently or preceding.

name: Microbiology: Virology
description: Virology is an upper division course covering the molecular genetics of viruses and their interactions with living organisms. Prer., BIOL 3020. Meets with BIOL 5140.

name: Animal Physiology
description: An examination of how invertebrates and vertebrates have met the problems of survival through physiological adaptations. Prer., BIOL 1300/1310 (formerly BIOL 1200), BIOL 1350/1360 (formerly BIOL 1210), and BIOL 3020.

name: Plant Physiology
description: A comprehensive study of the physiology of photosynthetic organisms emphasizing molecular and cellular biology. Prer., BIOL 1200 or BIOL 1300/1310, BIOL 1210 or BIOL 1350/1360; prior or concurrent enrollment in CHEM 3101.

name: Molecular Pathogenesis of Infectious Diseases
description: An examination of the molecular mechanisms utilized by medically significant eukaryotic microorganisms to cause disease. Emphasis will be placed on strategies for host invasion, immune evasion, and the molecular and immunological techniques used to explore these mechanisms. Prer., BIOL 3020.

name: Developmental Biology
description: Lecture. Examines cellular development with emphasis on vertebrate systems and experimental analysis. Prer., BIOL 3020.

name: General Ecology
description: A survey of environmental relationships of plants and animals. Topics include speciation, abiotic, and biotic limiting factors, population, community and ecosystem dynamics, and terrestrial and aquatic biomes. Spring (even years). Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Sustainability. Prer., BIOL 1300/1310 (formerly BIOL 1200), BIOL 1350/1360 (formerly BIOL 1210). Course typically offered: Fall

name: Conservation Biology
description: The major focus is the application of biological and ecological principles to preserve biodiversity. Ultimate sources and current worldwide losses of biological diversity are emphasized.
