description: The content of these courses will vary from time to time and reflect the areas of current interest in Computer Science. As the courses continually change, students may take the course several times for elective credit. Prer., Instructor consent, College of Engineering students only.

name: Selected Topics in Computer Science
description: The content of these courses will vary from time to time and reflect the areas of current interest in Computer Science. As the courses continually change, students may take the course several times for elective credit. Prer., Instructor consent, College of Engineering students only.

name: Selected Topics in Computer Science
description: The content of these courses will vary from time to time and reflect the areas of current interest in Computer Science. As the courses continually change, students may take the course several times for elective credit. Prer., Instructor consent, College of Engineering students only.

name: Compiler Design I
description: Underlying theory and design techniques for compilers. Lexical analysis, top-down and bottom-up parsing algorithms, runtime storage management, syntax directed translation schemes, intermediate code generation. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Summit. Prer., CS 3160 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 4700 or CS 5700 with a grade of “C” or better. College of Engineering students only. Meets with CS 5100. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Computer Architecture I
description: Course covers fundamentals of computer design, instruction set principles and examples, pipelining, advanced pipelining and instruction-level parallelism, memory-hierarchy design and survey of design issues in storage, interconnection network and multiprocessor systems. Prer., CS 2160 or ECE 3430 with a grade of “C” or better. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Computer Networks
description: Course focuses on the basic network and protocol concepts and principles with practical hands-on exercises on network management, network programming, and network planning through the use of industry simulators. Topics include: Internet protocols and routing, local area networks, basic TCP/IP programming, congestion control, packet switching and routing, quality-of-service, and network management. Prer., CS 2060 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 2150 or MATH 2150 with a grade of “C” or better. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Advanced Software Engineering
description: Software methodologies and practices. A course project provides student teams practical application of software engineering techniques from conception through planning, development, assessment/testing, deployment, and operations while experiencing the related challenges. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Summit. Prer., CS 3300 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with CS 5300. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Software Requirements Analysis and Specification
description: Techniques and tools for requirements analysis and specification. Requirements languages and notations. Specification completeness and consistency. Team project in the creation and analysis of a specification of a software system. Current topics in requirements engineering explored in research. Prer., Knowledge of modern programming languages, discrete structures, CS 1450 or GDD 2200 with a grade of “C” or better. Recommended: CS 3300 or equivalent. Meets with CS 5310. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Software Design
description: Covers methodologies and tools for design of sequential, parallel and distributed software systems. Design language; graphical design representations. Data abstraction, data dictionaries. Data flow design and diagrams. Object-oriented design. Documentation. Team project in the design of a system. Prer., Knowledge of modern programming languages, discrete structures, CS 1450 or GDD 2200 with a grade of “C” or better or equivalent. Recommended: CS 3300 or equivalent. Meets with CS 5320. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Software Maintenance
description: Discussion/application of corrective, adaptive, perfective, and preventive software maintenance techniques and tools. Software systems analysis, reverse engineering, re-engineering, regression testing, and configuration management. Project on existing software system. Prer., Knowledge of modern programming languages, discrete structures, CS 1450 or GDD 2200 with a grade of “C” or better or equivalent. Recommended: CS 3300 or equivalent. Meets with CS 5340. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Software Project Management
description: Planning, scheduling, costing of projects. Measuring progress, predicting success, controlling failure. Management tools and their use. Effectiveness and efficiency of software engineering environments. Distributed software development. Quality control standards and practices. Prer., Knowledge of modern programming languages, discrete structures, CS 1450 or GDD 2200 with a grade of “C” or better or equivalent. Recommended: CS 3300 or equivalent. Meets with CS 5350. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Software Engineering Research
description: Software methodologies and practices- and where we can improve! A course project will encourage research specific to software engineering with peer review and support. Prer., CS 4300/CS 5300 encouraged. Meets with CS 5372. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Quantum Software and AI Engineering
description: This course provides the basic principles and practices in the fields of Quantum Software Engineering and AI Engineering, including Quantum AI. Prer., CS 3300 or CS 3080 with a grade of “C” or better. CS 3820 and CS 4820/5820 or CS 3850 with a grade of “C” or better. Python programming recommended. Meets with CS 5410. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Database Systems I
description: Course introduces general database concepts as well as database system technology. The course covers ER and R data models, R-algebra, SQL, data storage and indexing, query optimization, database design and security. Prer., CS 2150 or MATH 2150 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 3020 or CS 3060 or CS 3080 with a grade of “C” or better. College of Engineering students only. Meets with CS 5420. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Data Mining
description: This course covers introduction to fundamental concepts, data warehousing, data pre-processing, association rules, cluster analysis, classification and prediction, frequent pattern mining, complex data mining applications and trends in data mining. Prer., CS 4420 or CS 5420 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with CS 5435. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Big Data
description: Extensive experience in multiple paradigms for Big Data, focusing on: 1) Large-scale data analysis techniques: statistics basics, machine learning, classification; 2) parallel programming techniques: Nvidia GPUs/CUDA; 3) Cloud computing techniques: Map-Reduce, Hadoop, Pig, Hive. Prer., ECE 3610 or MATH 3810 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 3060 with a grade of “C” or better. College of Engineering students only. Meets with CS 5440. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Data Visualization
description: Animation: basic principles, physically based modeling, algorithms for animation, constraint optimization, use of dynamics in animations, and teleological modeling. Scientific Visualization: overview, foundational techniques, and applications. Prer., CS 2300 or MATH 3130 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 4720 with a grade of “C” or better or instructor consent. Meets with DASE 4770. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Operating Systems I
description: Introduces concepts, terminology, and algorithms of operating systems. Describes semaphores, processes, virtual mappings, interrupts, resource allocation and management, protection, synchronization, scheduling, queuing and communication as applied to operating system design and implementation. Prer., CS 2060 or ECE 1021 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 2080 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 4200 or CS 5200 or ECE 4480 with a grade of “C” or better. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Computer-based Optimization
description: Computer-Based optimization techniques including simulation, modeling, heuristic methods, genetic algorithms, simulated annealing, duality theory, dynamic programming, and queuing theory. Prer., ECE 1021 or CS 1120 or CS 1450 or GDD 2200 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with DASE 4570.

name: Real-Time Operating Systems
description: This course introduces real-time theory and software engineering for real-time operating system (RTOS) and real-time system development. The topics include principles of real-time system design, cross-compilation for embedded system development, multitasking concurrency, scheduling and timing analysis, real-time task management, task synchronization, inter-task communication, and considerations for multicore systems. Prer., MATH 2150 or CS 2150 with a grade of “C” or better; and CS 4200 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with CS 5590.

name: Numerical Computing
description: Algorithms for the solution of nonlinear equations, interpolation and approximation, differentiation, integration, systems of linear equations, ordinary differential equations and least squares. Prer., CS 1450 or GDD 2200 with a grade of “C” or better; MATH 1360 with a grade of “C” or better; MATH 3130 or CS 2300 with a grade of “C” or better. College of Engineering students only. Meets with CS 5600. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Applied Convex Optimization: Applications and Algorithms
description: Methods to solve convex optimization problems using the software package CVX. Emphasis on various applications: statistics, machine learning, finance, network routing, and control. Topics include convex functions and sets, semidefinite programming, duality, gradient descent, Newton’s method. Prer., CS 2300 or MATH 3130 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 4700 or CS 4720 with a grade of “C” or better; and MATH 1350 with a grade of “C” or better; or instructor consent. Meets with CS 5610. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Computability, Automata and Formal Languages
description: Finite automata and regular expressions, context-free grammars, context-free languages, and pushdown automata, Turning machines, undecidability, the Chomsky hierarchy of formal languages, computational complexity and intractable problems. Prer., CS 2150 or MATH 2150 with a grade of “C” or better. College of Engineering students only. Meets with CS 5700. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Evolutionary Computation
description: Introduction to evolutionary computation with emphasis on genetic algorithms. Includes evolution strategies, evolutionary programming, schemata fitness functions and classifiers, current research topics, messy algorithms, adaptive landscapes. Prer., ECE 3610 or MATH 3810 or QUAN 2010 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 3160 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 4720 or CS 4820 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with DASE 4710 and CS 5710. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
description: Design methodologies; divide-and-conquer, exhaustive search, dynamic programming. Time and space complexity measures, analysis of algorithms. Survey of important algorithms for searching, sorting, graph manipulation. Tractability: class P and NP, NP complete problems. Prer., CS 1450 or GDD 2200 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 2150 or MATH 2150 with a grade of “C” or better. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Algorithmic Game Theory and Multiagent Systems
description: An overview of game theory with emphasis on computational applications. Voting, auctions, zero-sum games, equilibrium concepts, and multiagent learning are covered. Examples draw from engineering, economic, and social models, including electronic commerce, network routing, and robotics. Prer., CS 1450 or GDD 2200 with a grade of “C” or better; MATH 3810 or ECE 3610 or QUAN 2010 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 4700 or CS 4720 with a grade of “C” or better or instructor consent. Meets with CS 5730. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Networks, Crowds, and Markets: Reasoning about a connected world
description: This course introduces students to the multidisciplinary field of Network Science. Topics include graph theory, modeling the spread of disease and opinion in networks, consensus, measuring the importance of network nodes, pagerank, and influencing social behavior in networks. Prer., CS 2150 or MATH 2150 with a grade of “C” or better; MATH 1360 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 1450 or GDD 2200 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 2300 or MATH 3130 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with CS 5740. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Complexity, Patterns and Geometric Modeling Advanced Techniques
description: This course will cover curves and surfaces including Bezier, B-Splines, NURBS and other advanced topics including manifolds, complexity of patterns including neural rendering. Prer., CS 4800/5800 or permission of instructor. Meets with CS 5760.

name: Advanced 3D Games and Digital Content Creation
description: Populating virtual worlds with characters and objects. Concentrates on current technology and advanced topics using graphics and VR technology. Typical topics include graphics engines, landscape specializations, wrapping techniques, complex scenes, lighting, shadows, motion control, collisions, dynamics, image-based rendering, multiplayer games, etc., plus advanced features from Siggraph and others. Prer., CS 4800 or CS 5800 with a grade of “C” or better. College of Engineering students only. Meets with CS 5780. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Wearable Computing and Complex systems
description: Wearable computing with an emphasis on complex systems research is an important area of research. This course will cover concepts and related techniques, and state of the art issues. This course will provide an excellent basis for students who are interested in computer graphics and virtual reality research. Prer., CS 4800/5800 with a grade of “C” or better or permission of the instructor. HNRS students please reach out to department for permission number. Meets with CS 5790. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Computer Graphics
description: Fundamental areas of modern raster computer graphics: hardware, software, data structures, mathematical modeling, user interface and manipulation of graphical objects. A subset of the two-dimensional GKS is examined and implemented with emphasis placed upon segmented display files and instance modeling. Basic to all graphic programs written are the ergonomic requirements of the user. Required programs are in the areas of animation, paint systems, polygon filling and clipping, and curve generation. Prer., CS 1450 or GDD 2200 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 2300 or MATH 3130 with a grade of “C” or better. College of Engineering students only. HNRS students please reach out to department for permission number. Meets with CS 5800. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Artificial Intelligence
description: Course covers the foundation of artificial intelligence: search techniques, first-order predicate calculus and knowledge representation. Also covers advanced topics such as speech and natural language processing and learning. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Writing Intensive. Prer., CS 2150 or MATH 2150 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 3160 with a grade of “C” or better or instructor consent. Meets with CS 5820. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Machine Learning
description: Introduction to machine learning followed by a selection of machine learning topics such as regression, Bayesisan learning, Hidden Markov Models, support vector machine, clustering and reinforcement learning. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Writing Intensive. Prer., CS 2150 or MATH 2150 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 2300 or MATH 3130 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 3160 with a grade of “C” or better or instructor consent. Meets with DASE 4860. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Introduction to Artificial Neural Networks
description: The course will cover neural network architectures and learning algorithms. Topics include biological motivation, perceptions, back-propagation, self-organizing maps, recurrent networks, and deep learning. Prer., MATH 2350 with a grade of “C” or better or equivalent; good programming skills. Meets with CS 5870. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Reinforcement Learning
description: Markov Decision Processes, Dynamic Programming, Monte Carlo Methods, Temporal Difference Learning, Q-learning,  Reinforcement Learning with Function Approximation: DQN, Double DQN, Eligibility Traces, Policy Search Methods, Monte Carlo Tree Search. Prer., CS 2150 or MATH 2150 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 2300 or MATH 3130 with a grade of “C” or better; and CS 3160 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with CS 5880.

name: Reinforcement Learning
description: Markov Decision Processes, Dynamic Programming, Monte Carlo Methods, Temporal Difference Learning, Q-learning,  Reinforcement Learning with Function Approximation: DQN, Double DQN, Eligibility Traces, Policy Search Methods, Monte Carlo Tree Search. Prer., CS 2150 or MATH 2150 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 2300 or MATH 3130 with a grade of “C” or better; and CS 3160 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with CS 5885.

name: Computational Linguistics
description: Approaches to syntactic processing of natural language: issues in semantic interpretation, pragmatics, or the impact of context and world knowledge of natural language understanding and generation of natural language responses. Prer., CS 2150 or MATH 2150 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 2300 or MATH 3130 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 3160 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with CS 5890. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Introduction to Computer Security
description: Students will learn basic cryptography, user authentication, access control, malicious software, network attacks and protection, software security, and operating system security. Students will also perform hands-on security lab exercises. Prer., CS 3300 with a grade of “C” or better; Senior standing. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Defensive Cyber Operations
description: The course teaches students with advanced technical skills for defensive cyber operations. The content includes advanced TTPs with hands-on defensive cyber operation experiments. The course equips students with key technical skills for conducting real-world defensive cyber operations. Prer., CS 3920 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with CS 5915. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Introduction to Applied Cryptography
description: Basic security issues in computer communication, classical cryptographic algorithms, symmetric-key cryptography, public-key cryptography, authentication, and digital signatures. Prer., CS 2150 or MATH 2150 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 3020 or CS 3060 or CS 3080 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with CS 5920. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Privacy and Censorship
description: This class will cover two topics:  privacy from the perspective of organization and individuals, and censorship techniques that censors use to monitor citizen’s Internet use and block unwanted network traffic.  You will build your knowledge about privacy and censorship by learning about technology-related privacy concerns and mitigation. Prer., CS 2080 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with CS 5930. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Ethical Hacking
description: Explores the methodologies surrounding ethical hacking and penetration testing. Students will learn various penetration testing techniques according to proven methodologies from NIST, NSA, and EC-Council. Students will learn and exercise reconnaissance, exploitation, analysis, and reporting methods. Prer., CS 3300 with a grade of “C” or better. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Homeland Security and Cyber Security
description: This course examines how homeland security safeguards the United States from domestic catastrophic destruction and investigates cyber security as a priority homeland security concern since a coordinated cyber attack against critical infrastructure could produce the worst catastrophe in the nation’s history. Meets with CS 5950. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: System Security
description: This course continues deeper exploration of the security of systems comprising components, connections, and software. System security requires a holistic view to identify security problems and devise solutions. Prer., CS 2080 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 4910 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with CS 5980. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Cybersecurity Metrics and Quantification
description: This course systematically introduces the state-of-the-art in the field of cybersecurity metrics and quantification, including what to measure, how to measure, and how to leverage what can be measured for various cybersecurity decision-making and risk management purposes. Prer., CS 4910 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with CS 5985. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Tor Anonymity Networks
description: This course introduces the most popular anonymous networks called Tor networks. The course covers basic concept of Tor networks up to state-of-art research on Tor. Prer., CS 4220 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with CS 5990.

name: Introduction to Computer Science Research
description: This course will introduce the basics of doing CS research and survey ongoing research in the field. Students will read research papers across multiple CS topics and prepare written analyses. Students will write a survey paper suitable for publication. Prer., Graduate Students only.

name: Intensive Computer Science for Graduate Students
description: Intended for prospective graduate students with extensive programming experience. Covers concepts in CS 1150 and CS 1450. Can substitute for these courses in satisfying entrance requirements for M.S. in Computer Science. Does not count towards M.S.or B.S. degrees. Not open to undergraduate. Prer., Knowledge of high-level programming language.

name: Compiler Design
description: Underlying theory and design techniques for compilers. Lexical analysis, top-down and bottom-up parsing algorithms, runtime storage management, syntax directed translation schemes, and intermediate code generation. Prer., CS 3160, and CS 4700 or CS 5700; College of Engineering students only. Meets with CS 4100. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Computer Architecture I
description: Course covers fundamentals of computer design, instruction set principles and examples, pipelining, advanced pipelining and instruction-level parallelism, memory-hierarchy design and survey of design issues in storage, interconnection network and multiprocessor systems. Prer., CS 2160, Graduate standing.

name: Computer Communication
description: The subject of transmitting information between processors is described in detail. The student is expected to have maturity with hardware and/or real-time concepts. Communication systems, from simple to asynchronous point-to-point links, to those based on complex network architectures will be studied. Material will be oriented toward the computer scientist as a user, designer and evaluator of such systems. Terminology and concepts will be emphasized rather than detailed electronic or physical theory. Prer., CS 2060, CS 2080, and MATH 3810 or ECE 3610. Graduate students only.

name: Multimedia Computing and Communications
description: Design principles of multimedia authoring and communication systems. It covers the interface and characteristics of voice and video processing equipment, multimedia document architectures, media encoding/compression schemes, real-time scheduling of time critical multimedia documents, multimedia editors, multimedia communication standards and communication software. Prer., Graduate standing or instructor permission.

name: Advanced Internet and Web Systems
description: Advanced topics in Internet and WWW systems, TCP/IP network modules in kernel, content switching, web server technologies, web system management, load balancing, web security, and electronic commerce. Prer., CS 3010, CS 5220, or consent of instructor.

name: Advanced Software Engineering
description: Software methodologies and practices. A course project provides student teams practical application of software engineering techniques from conception thru planning, development, assessment/testing, deployment, and operations while experiencing the related challenges. Prer., CS 3300 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with CS 4300. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Software Requirements Analysis and Specification
description: Techniques and tools for requirements analysis and requirements specification. Requirements languages and notations. Specification completeness and consistency. Team project in the analysis and specification of a major software system. Prer., CS 1450 or equivalent, knowledge of a modern programming language and discrete structures. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Software Design
description: Covers a variety of methodologies and tools for design of sequential, parallel and distributed software systems. Design language; graphical design representations. Data abstraction, data dictionaries. Data flow design and diagrams. Object-oriented design. Documentation. Team project in the design of a major software system. Prer., Graduate students only. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Formal Methods of Software Systems Engineering
description: Elements of discrete mathematics. Formal mechanisms for specifying and verifying the correctness, reliability, and efficiency of software systems. State transition, regular expression, context free, and applicative models. Assertions, Hoare axioms, and weakest preconditions. State machine, algebraic, and operational specification techniques. Prer., Graduate students only.

name: Software Maintenance
description: Discussion and application of corrective, adaptive, perfective and preventive software maintenance techniques and tools. Related topics such as software systems analysis, reverse-engineering, re-engineering, regression testing and configuration management are examined. As a project, student teams maintain an existing software system. Prer., Knowledge of modern programming language, discrete structures, Graduate students only.

name: Software Project Management
description: Planning, scheduling, costing of projects. Measuring progress, predicting success, controlling failure. Management tools and their use. Effectiveness and efficiency of software engineering environments. Distributed software development. Quality control standards and practices. Prer., Knowledge of modern programming, NG language, data structures and algorithms, and discrete structures.

name: Software Product Assurance
description: Principles, techniques and tools for producing quality software systems. The first half of this course focuses on software product assurance processes. The second half covers a variety of software testing techniques. Prer., Graduate students only.

name: Software Testing for Mobile Devices and Embedded Systems
description: This course covers theoretical and practical aspects of Software Testing for mobile devices and embedded systems and introduces students to recent research in the area. Students develop a research proposal in the subject area on a topic of their choice. Prer., CS 1450 and either CS 3110 or CS 4500. Graduate students only. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Software Engineering Research
description: Software methodologies and practices- and where we can improve! A course project will encourage research specific to software engineering with peer review and support. Prer., CS 4300 or CS 5300 encouraged. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Object-Oriented Software Development
description: Principles of object-oriented problem-solving, object-oriented analysis and object-oriented design. Development of class hierarchies, use of polymorphism and inheritance, criteria for good design, semester project. Prer., CS 3300 or consent of instructor.

name: Software Systems Engineering Project Laboratory
description: Students participate in a project involving the development or maintenance of a software system intended for external distribution and use. Duties include requirements analysis, specification, design, implementation, testing, quality assurance, configuration management and documentation. Projects come from the university and from outside sources. Students are evaluated based on their project work and an oral presentation describing their work and critiquing their results. Prer., CS 5310, CS 5320, CS 5340, CS 5360.

name: Quantum Software and AI Engineering
description: This course provides the basic principles and practices in the fields of Quantum Software Engineering and AI Engineering, including Quantum AI. Prer., Knowledge of python programming is recommended. Meets with CS 4410. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Database Systems I
description: Course introduces general database concepts as well as database system technology. The course covers ER and R data models, R-algebra, SQL, data storage and indexing, query optimization, database design and security. Prer., CS 2150 or MATH 2150, and CS 3020 or CS 3060 or CS 3080. College of Engineering Graduate Students only. Meets with CS 4420. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Database Systems II
description: Course covers advanced database topics including transaction management, parallel and distributed databases, internet databases, decision support, data mining, object and object-relational database systems, spatial data management and other current research issues. Prer., CS 4420 or CS 5420.

name: Data Mining
description: This course covers introduction to fundamental concepts, data warehousing, data pre-processing, association rules, cluster analysis, classification and prediction, frequent pattern mining, complex data mining applications and trends in data mining. Prer., CS 4420 or 5420. Meets with CS 4435. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Big Data
description: Extensive experience in multiple paradigms for Big Data, focusing on: 1) Large-scale data analysis techniques: statistics basics, machine learning, classification; 2) parallel programming techniques: Nvidia GPUs/CUDA; 3) Cloud computing techniques: Map-Reduce, Hadoop, Pig, Hive. Prer., CS 3060, and either ECE 3610 or MATH 3810. Graduate students only. Meets with CS 4440.

name: KDD (Knowledge Discovery in Databases) Applications in Bioinformatics and Neurosciences
description: Both a theoretical and hands-on course that presents data mining concepts common to the art of KDD including Discretization, Rought Set Theory, Fuzzy Logic, Domain Adaptation and Discrete Finite Automata Trees. The application of these will be in terms of data mining with Weka, Matlab, Scal and Java. Prer., computer science familiarity. Prer., Graduate students only.

name: Intelligent Robotics
description: This course introduces students to the field of robotics. Topics include Robotics Operating System, Agents and agent-based system, swarm intelligence, Unmanned Vehicles (UGV, UAV, AUV), robot teaming, mission planning/management systems, path planning & obstacle avoidance. Prer., CS 2060, CS 2150 or MATH 2150, MATH 1360, CS 1450, CS 2300 or MATH 3130. Meets with CS 4460. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Data Visualization
description: The course offers conceptual and practical knowledge and data representation and visualization. Topics include overview, Data & Visualization Foundation, Human Perception, techniques, applications & history of visualization, and will incorporate utilization of Tableau & R for data visualization. Graduate Students Only.  Prer., CS 2300 or MATH 3130; CS 4720; or instructor consent. Meets with CS 4470.

name: Operating Systems I
description: Introduces concepts, terminology, and algorithms of operating systems. Describes semaphores, processes, virtual mappings, interrupts, resource allocation and management, protection, synchronization, scheduling, queuing and communication as applied to operating system design and implementation. Prer., CS 5200 with a grade of “C” or better or instructor permission. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Distributed Systems
description: Conveys insight into, and knowledge of, the principles and practice underlying the distributed systems, both Internet-based and otherwise. Describes major developments in inter-process communication, remote invocation, distributed file systems, replication and load balancing, distributed shared memory, and distributed multimedia systems. Prer., CS 4500 or CS 5500.

name: Operating System Support for Security
description: Covers the configuration and management of operating systems for security-related applications, OS hardening, access control, security policies, security and protection mechanisms, virtual machines, the exploits related to operating systems and their defenses, and mandatory access control and multilevel security. Prer., CS 2060, CS 2080.

name: Mobile and Wireless Systems
description: Considers aspects of mobile and wireless systems including the support for creating mobile applications, OS, programming, network protocols, security, and their interactions with web systems and cloud computing. Prer., CS 5220, Graduate students only.

name: Datacenters and Cloud Computing
description: This course focuses on recent research in cloud computing and datacenters, including automated cloud resource management, data center reliability, and secure and scalable data center design. Prer., CS 4500 or CS 5500; Graduate students only.

name: Computer Systems Performance Evaluation
description: Perspectives of performance evaluation, measurement techniques; hardware, software, and firmware tools, simulation techniques, analytical techniques; workload characterization, system selection; system tuning; performance tracking, performance prediction in the design phase and cost-benefit analysis. Prer., CS 4500 or CS 5500.

name: Real-Time Operating Systems
description: This course introduces real-time theory and software engineering for real-time operating system (RTOS) and real-time system development. The topics include principles of real-time system design, cross-compilation for embedded system development, multitasking concurrency, scheduling and timing analysis, real-time task management, task synchronization, inter-task communication, and considerations for multicore systems. Prer., MATH 2150 or CS 2150 with a grade of “C” or better; and CS 4200 with a grade of “C” or better. Meets with CS 4590.

name: Numerical Computing
description: Algorithms for the solution of nonlinear equations, interpolation and approximation, differentiation, integration, systems of linear equations, ordinary differential equations and least squares. Prer., CS 1450, MATH 1360, MATH 3130. Graduate students only. Meets with CS 4600. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Applied Convex Optimization: Applications and Algorithms
description: Methods to solve convex optimization problems using the software package CVX. Emphasis on various applications: statistics, machine learning, finance, network routing, and control. Topics include convex functions and sets, semidefinite programming, duality, gradient descent, Newton’s method. Prer., (CS 2300 or MATH 3130) and (CS 4700 or CS 4720) and MATH 1350 or instructor consent. Meets with CS 4610. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Discrete Simulation I
description: Examines concepts and methods of discrete event simulation. Compares major modeling methods. Discusses statistical issues including random number generation, arrival processes, analysis of simulation output, verification and validation of models and simulation programs. Describes in detail the use of a major discrete event simulation language. Discusses simulation level of detail and simplifying assumptions. Prer., CS 2080; ECE 3610 or MATH 3810.

name: Computability, Automata, and Formal Languages
description: Finite automata and regular expressions; context-free grammars, context-free languages, and pushdown automata; Turing machines; undecidability; the Chomsky Hierarchy of Formal Languages; computational complexity, and intractable problems. Prer., CS 2150 or MATH 2150. College of Engineering Graduate Students only. Meets with CS 4700. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Evolutionary Computation
description: Introduction to evolutionary computation with emphasis on genetic algorithms. Includes evolution strategies, evolutionary programming, schemata fitness functions and classifiers, current research topics, messy algorithms, and adaptive landscapes. Prer., ECE 3610 or MATH 3810 or QUAN 2010; and CS 5720 or CS 5820; or instructor permission. Meets with CS 4710, DASE 4710.

name: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
description: Design methodologies: divide-and-conquer, exhaustive search, dynamic programming. Time and space complexity measures, analysis of algorithms. Survey of important algorithms for searching, sorting, and graph manipulation. Tractability: Class P and NP, NP-complete problems. Prer., CS 1450 and CS 2150 or MATH 2150. College of Engineering Graduate Students only. Meets with CS 4720. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Algorithmic Game Theory and Multiagent Systems
description: An overview of game theory with emphasis on computational applications. Voting, auctions, zero-sum games, equilibrium concepts, and multiagent learning are covered. Examples draw from engineering, economic, and social models, including electronic commerce, network routing, and robotics. Prer., CS 1450; MATH 3810 or ECE 3610 or QUAN 2010; CS 4700 or CS 4720 or instructor consent. Meets with CS 4730. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Networks, Crowds, and Markets: Reasoning about a connected world
description: This course introduces students to the multidisciplinary field of Network Science. Topics include graph theory, modeling the spread of disease and opinion in networks, consensus, measuring the importance of network nodes, pagerank, and influencing social behavior in networks. Prer., CS 2150 or MATH 2150, MATH 1360, CS 1450, and CS 2300 or MATH 3130. Meets with CS 4740. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Computational Geometry with Deep Learning
description: Computational complexity of geometric problems within the framework of analysis of algorithms. Stress on geometric searching, intersection problems, particularly of rectangles, and fundamental algorithms. Practical applications of concepts developed can be found in computer graphics, analysis of algorithms, spatial data structures and VLSI system design. Prer., CS 4720/5720, CS 4800/5800, or instructor consent. Meets with CS 4750. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Complexity, Patterns and Geometric Modeling Advanced Techniques
description: This course will cover curves and surfaces including Bezier, B-Splines, NURBS and other advanced topics including manifolds, complexity of patterns including neural rendering. Prer., CS 4800/5800 or permission of instructor. Meets with CS 4760.

name: Computer Graphics Animation & Scientific Visualization Techniques
description: Animation: basic principle, physically based modeling, algorithms for animation, constraint optimization, use of dynamics in animation, teleological modeling. Scientific visualization: overview, foundation techniques, and applications. Prer., CS 4800 or CS 5800. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: VR/AR/XR Technologies, 3D Games & Digital Contents Creations
description: Populating virtual worlds with characters and objects, this course will concentrate on current technology and advance topics using graphics and VR technology. Typical topics included are graphics engines, landscape specializations, wrapping techniques, complex scenes, lighting, shadows, motion control, collision, dynamics, image based rendering, multiplayer games, etc. plus advanced features from Siggraph and others. Prer., CS 4800 or CS 5800 or instructor consent. Graduate students only. Meets with CS 4780. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Wearable Computing and Complex Systems
description: Wearable computing with an emphasis on complex systems research is an important area of research. This course will cover concepts and related techniques, and state of the art issues. This course will provide an excellent basis for students who are interested in computer graphics and virtual reality research. Prer., CS 4800/5800 with a grade of “C” or better or permission of the instructor. HNRS students please reach out to department for permission number. Meets with CS 4790. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Computer Graphics
description: Fundamental areas of modern raster computer graphics; hardware, software, data structures, mathematical modeling, user interface and manipulation of graphical objects. A subset of the two dimensional GKS is examined and implemented with emphasis placed upon segmented display files and instance modeling. Basic to all graphic programs written are the ergonomic requirements of the user. Required programs are in the areas of animation, paint systems, polygon filling and clipping, and curve generation. Prer., CS 1450 or GDD 2200 with a grade of “C” or better; CS 2300 or MATH 3130 with a grade of “C” or better. College of Engineering students only or permission of instructor. HNRS students please reach out to department for permission number. Meets with CS 4800. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Topics in Computer Graphics
description: Examines the mathematical and physical models used to produce realistic three dimensional images. Topics include perspective viewing, hidden surface removal, shading, fractals, and rag tracing. Prer., CS 4800 or CS 5800. Meets with CS 4810. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Artificial Intelligence
description: Course covers the foundation of artificial intelligence: search techniques, first-order predicate calculus and knowledge representation. Also covers advanced topics such as speech and natural language processing and learning. Prer., CS 2150 or MATH 2150, and CS 3160, or instructor consent. Meets with CS 4820. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Computer Vision
description: Representation and manipulation of digital images, Fourier analysis of images, enhancement techniques in spatial and frequency domain, segmentation procedures, digital geometry, region and boundary representation, texture processing, pattern recognition and application to robotics. Prer., MATH 2350 or consent of instructor. Meets with MATH 5840.

name: Bioinformatics and Computational Biology
description: Review of molecular and cell biology; bioinformatics databases; pairwise sequence alignment algorithms; Markov Chains, Hidden Markov Models; evolutionary models; Phylogenetic trees; gene recognition; protein structure prediction. Prer., ECE 3610 or MATH 3810, and CS 4720 or CS 5720; Graduate students only. Meets with CS 4850. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Machine Learning
description: Introduction to machine learning followed by a selection of machine learning topics such as regression, Bayesian learning, Hidden Markov Models, support vector machine, clustering and reinforcement learning. Prer., MATH 2150; MATH 3130 or CS 2300; CS 3160 or instructor consent; Graduate standing. Meets with CS 4860. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Introduction to Artificial Neural Networks
description: The course will cover basic neural network architecture and learning algorithms. Topics include biological motivation, perceptions, back-propagation, self-organizing maps, recurrent networks, and deep learning. Prer., MATH 2350 or equivalent; good programming skills; Graduate students only. Meets with CS 4870. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Information Retrieval
description: Information retrieval focuses on algorithms and approaches to the search for information in documents, in databases, and on the Web. Topics include index construction and compression, probabilistic retrieval, language models, text classification, classification, clustering, web crawling, and web search. Prer., Graduate standing or instructor permission.

name: Computational Linguistics
description: Approaches to syntactic processing of natural language: issues in semantic interpretation, pragmatics, or the impact of context and world knowledge of natural language understanding and generation of natural language responses. Prer., CS 2150 or MATH 2150, MATH 3130 or equivalent, and CS 3160. Meets with CS 4890. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Fundamentals of Computer/Network Security
description: Introduction to the study of computer and network security from the view of information warfare. Topics include information system threats, vulnerabilities and defensive mechanisms (cryptography, authentication digital signatures, PKI, etc.). Prer., CS 2080 and MATH 2150.

name: Defensive Cyber Operations
description: The course teaches students with advanced technical skills for defensive cyber operations, including advanced defensive cyber operations and advanced research activities. High-quality projects would lead to publications. Prer., CS 5220 and CS 5910. Meets with CS 4915. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Applied Cryptography for Secure Communication
description: Basic security issues in computer communication, classical cryptographic algorithms, symmetric-key cryptography, public-key cryptography, authentication, and digital signatures. Prer., MATH 2150; CS 3020 or CS 3060; Graduate students only. Meets with CS 4920.

name: Privacy and Censorship
description: This class will cover two topics:  privacy from the perspective of organization and individuals, and censorship techniques that censors use to monitor citizen’s Internet use and block unwanted network traffic.  You will build your knowledge about privacy and censorship by learning about technology related privacy concerns and mitigation. Prer., CS 2080, Graduate standing. Meets with CS 4930. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Homeland Security and Cyber Security
description: This course examines how homeland security safeguards the United States from domestic catastrophic destruction and investigates cyber security as a priority homeland security concern since a coordinated cyber attack against critical infrastructure could produce the worst catastrophe in the nation’s history. Meets with CS 4950. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Wireless and Embedded Systems Security
description: This course studies security of wireless and embedded systems and their use for last-mile networking, including the basics in wireless and embedded networks, security research in last-mile networking, and security developments in cyber-physical-systems and internet-of-things applications. Prer., CS 4910 or CS 5910, CS 4220 or CS 5220, or instructor consent. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Software Security
description: Software security covers theories, techniques and tools for secure software design, threat analysis, secure coding, and vulnerability analysis. Prer., CS 5910 or instructor consent. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: System Security
description: This course continues deeper exploration of the security of systems comprising components, connections, and software. System security requires a holistic view to identify security problems and devise solutions. Prer., CS 2080, CS 4910. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Cybersecurity Metrics and Quantification
description: This course systematically introduces the state-of-the-art in the field of cybersecurity metrics and quantification, including what to measure, how to measure, and how to leverage what can be measured for cybersecurity decision-making and risk management purposes. It includes research activities. Prer., CS 5220, CS 5910, and CS 5950. Meets with CS 4985. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Information Assurance Capstone Project Laboratory
description: Students participate in information assurance projects involving the vulnerability analysis and hardening of software systems. Students are evaluated based on their project work, how they integrate what they have learned in the required information assurance core courses, and an oral presentation at the end of the course. Prer., CS 5200, CS 5220, CS 5520, CS 5910, CS 5920; Graduate students only.

name: Introduction to Computer Science Research
description: This course, required for CS first-year Ph.D. students, will introduce the basics of doing CS research and survey ongoing research in the field. Students will read research papers across multiple CS topics and prepare written analyses. Prer., Graduate students only. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Technological Transfer, Patents and IP in Engineering
description: Technological transfer process including discovery through invention to commercialization. Forms of IP protection including copyrights and patents. Students will read/write patent applications. Prer., Permission of instructor.

name: Distributed Networks
description: Deals with complex communications systems in depth. Packet switching networks, local area networks, satellite systems, the open systems interconnect (OSI) reference model, and the development of communications software. Prer., CS 5220.

name: Topics in Software Systems Engineering
description: Advanced topics and current research issues in software engineering. Possible topics include software engineering environments, requirements, design, testing, software metrics, configuration management, maintenance, software cost analysis, and distributed software. Prer., CS 5310 or CS 5350.

name: The Design and Modeling of Class Interfaces and Contracts
description: Past and present work related to specifying the semantics of a class using assertions are examined. The BON method is presented. Prer., CS 5380.

name: Virtual Reality and Computer-Human Interaction
description: The course will focus on the so-called ultimate form of interaction between human and machine, creating virtual or artificial world. The basic idea and various input devices will be discussed. Several advanced papers in this area will be covered. Some of these ideas will be implemented through a term project. Prer., CS 4800/5800 with a grade of “C” or better and one of the following courses with a grade of “C” or better: CS 4470/5470, CS 4780/5780, CS 4790/5790 or instructor permission. HNRS students please reach out to department for permission number. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Seminar in Artificial Intelligence
description: Research seminar treating contemporary results in the theory and applications of artificial intelligence. Prer., CS 5820 or instructor permission.

name: Seminar on Deep Learning
description: A research seminar on contemporary results in the theory and applications of artificial neural networks. Will discuss seminal and recent papers. Students will be required to perform projects, give presentations and write papers. Prer., CS 4820/5820 or CS 4860/5860 or CS 4870/5870 or CS 4890/5890 or instructor permission. Advanced Graduate Status.

name: Advanced System Security Design
description: Advanced topics in network and system security, including firewall design, network intrusion detection, tracking and prevention, virus detection, programming language and OS support for security and wireless network security. Prer., CS 5910, CS 5920, or instructor permission. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Advanced Topics in Network Security
description: Covers advanced topics in network security such as Kerberos, PGP, IPSec, VPNs, SSL, SET, Smart cards, Steganography, Watermarking and Biometric Encryption. Research papers may be discussed. Prer., CS 5920.

name: Advanced Topics in Web Security and Privacy
description: This course will explore a series of important topics in web security and privacy. It is a combination of introductory lectures, homework, student presentations of research papers, and research projects. Prer., CS 5910 or consent of instructor.

name: Masters Thesis
description: Masters Thesis. Prer., Consent of instructor.

name: Masters Project
description: Masters Project.  Prer., Consent of instructor.

name: Graduate Internship
description: Educational readings and reporting associated with a computer science internship related to students’ graduate studies. Must be enrolled in a CS graduate program and have faculty sponsor.

name: MSCS GMI Portfolio
description: Completed works with interdisciplinary focus to be submitted to various animation or graphics festivals. The GMI program Portfolio course is approved for only MSCS GMI students. This course will now allow limited number of CS Graduate and other qualified students based on instructor permission. Prer., MSCS GMI students or permission of the instructor. HNRS students please reach out to department for permission number.

name: PhD Dissertation
description: Prer., Acceptance into program.

name: Undergraduate Independent Study in Computer Science
description: Prer., Consent of instructor.

name: Undergraduate Independent Study in Computer Science Research
description: Prer., Consent of Instructor.

name: Undergraduate Independent Study in Computer Science Entrepreneurship Focus
description: Prer., Consent of Instructor

name: Graduate Independent Study in Computer Science
description: Independent and creative work in the Computer Science area for graduate students. Prer., Approval of program advisor.

name: Candidate for Degree
description: Candidate for Degree.  Prer., Consent of instructor.

name: Career Exploration
description: This course is designed for high school students to learn about themselves in relation to the world of work. Students will enhance their individual Career and Academic Plans (ICAP) through various career assessments, experiential activities, and career mentoring.

name: Introduction to Human Services
description: An introductory overview of the essential elements and principles of the field of human services. Topics include history of helping, the relationship between client and helper, and working in human service settings. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Human Growth and Development
description: This course is aimed at preparing human services professionals to serve individuals, families, and communities by providing a basic foundation for understanding how human beings develop across the lifespan from a topical approach. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Infectious Diseases in Addiction Treatment
description: This course will focus on the complex relationship between the client’s drugs of choice, lifestyle choices, and physiological health. Discussions will include immune system health, liver function, harm reduction, and specific diseases such as HIV and hepatitis.

name: Pharmacology I
description: Training in pharmacology is a cornerstone of counseling and a major part of what differentiates addictions counseling from other mental health disciplines. This course will provide a solid base of knowledge about the drugs of abuse, including what is happening physiologically and behaviorally.

name: Ethics I & II
description: This class will focus on ethical issues specific to the practice of addition counseling to include information on the jurisprudence and laws for practicing psychotherapy in Colorado. Conduct, ethical boundaries, and ethical violations will be discussed, in addition to ethical decision making models. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Introduction to Principles of Addiction Treatment
description: This course presents models of addiction, defines addiction treatment, presents the National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA) principles of effective treatment, and outlines various types of addiction treatment and use of evidence-based treatment approaches. It also covers addiction counselor credentialing in Colorado. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Society, Health and Behavior. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Fieldwork in Human Services I
description: Students will engage in an approved Human Services site appropriate for their chosen emphasis area as an introduction to the Human Services field. Additionally, students will learn and practice interview skills, resume building, professional communication, etc. Prer., COUN 2000 and COUN 3110. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Introduction to Addiction Counseling Skills
description: Provides students a framework and counseling model for working with clients with substance misuse and addiction. Teaches counseling skills needed to help clients through the change process. Basic substance use counseling skills will be observed, and practiced. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Culturally Informed Treatment
description: This class provides a basic foundation for understanding how cultural competence, awareness, and sensitivity can improve quality of care and increase positive outcomes. Cultural variables and individual differences when considered in a cultural context can become strengths and resources for recovery. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Society, Health and Behavior. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Pharmacology I, II & Infectious Diseases
description: This course covers substances of use, including physiological and behavioral effects. It explores the neurobiological basis of addiction and how substances produce neurochemical changes in the brain’s reward pathway. Substance-use related transmission of disease(s) will also be discussed. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Career Planning and Employment Services
description: This course provides career planning, and job search and placement skills and activities. This course includes job analysis, supported employment, and transition services. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Arts, Humanities, and Cultures. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Interpersonal Communication, Interviewing and Mediation Skills
description: Students in the human service professions will learn interpersonal skills, self-awareness, communication, negotiation and conflict resolution skills. This course will help students understand the power of effective communication and barriers impacting communication. Conflict, anger, resistance, control and power will be discussed. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Professional Orientation & Case Management in Rehabilitation
description: This course reviews rehabilitation services within their organizational contexts. Application of the rehabilitation model focuses on interviewing, assessment, service planning, and coordination of services. Service delivery models and their application through public and private resources.

name: Ethics & Values in Human Services
description: Provides an introductory overview of the essential elements and principles of ethics in the field of human services. Topics include history of helping, the relationship between client and helper, and ethical issues when working in human service settings. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

name: Clinical Assessment and Treatment Planning
description: This course will consider the differences between screening and assessment and use of assessment instruments. Includes biopsychosocial interview, assessing risk for self-harm, identifying cultural needs and supports, problem domains, determining stage of readiness for change and ASAM (American Society of Addiction Medicine). Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Group Dynamics and Group Process
description: This course includes studies that provide a broad understanding of group formation/development, group dynamics, and group leadership styles. Undergraduate students only - All levels. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Motivational Interviewing I & II
description: This course examines the stages of change and motivational interviewing (MI) skills necessary for creating positive change. Students will be introduced to the process of change and how to use MI techniques in working with clients. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Digital Health & Wellness
description: Technology has changed how we work and play. Overuse of technology poses new health concerns both physical and psychological. Understanding digital health and emotional wellbeing of children, adolescents, and adults helps bring balance to our online life. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Social & Emotional Development
description: Study of how social and emotional development, birth through adolescence influences adulthood. Introduction to the theories and factors that shape behavior, self-image, interactions and relationships. Exploration of biological and environmental influences will be discussed. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Therapeutic Play
description: Therapeutic play is an introduction to therapeutic play interventions and activities for children. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Military Family Systems
description: This course is designed for students who desire to work in support settings serving military personnel, active and retired, and their families. The course will follow the military life-cycle including enlistment, military career separation and post military life. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Introduction to the Counseling Profession
description: Provides an overview of the field of counseling and human services. Students will learn about career opportunities in this field and the roles and functions of professional counselors in various settings. The history of the field and future trends will be presented.

name: Adventure Education and Experiential Learning
description: This training is designed for educators and community leaders wanting to develop and enhance their positive group facilitation skills and leadership strategies. This course will provide experiential ideas for developing group trust, enhancing teamwork, and encouraging cooperation. Meets with COUN 5070. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Medical and Psychosocial Aspects of Disability
description: Stages of adjustment to disability, impact of age at onset, impact on family. Introduction to health perspectives, etiology, and treatment of disabling conditions related to cognition, emotion, and addiction, etc. Includes the interplay of physical, psychosocial and vocational implications. Prer., COUN 3200.

name: Study Abroad in Counseling
description: In this course students will immerse themselves in an international study of counseling through an overseas experience. Course topics include the history, culture, education, and counseling practices of the chosen country. Meets with COUN 6111.

name: Career Assessment & Transitions
description: This course will introduce career development theories and the process of working with clients in transition including, military veterans/spouses, career changers, older adults, and youth with diverse career paths. Course typically offered: Rarely Offered

name: Military/Veteran Leadership, Advocacy and Support
description: This course is designed for students who desire to work in settings serving military personnel, active and retired, and their families. The human services course emphasizes qualities of effective leadership, advocacy, and support skills.

name: Wellness, Resilience and Emotional Intelligence
description: Focuses on the personal dispositions necessary to provide effective service in a helping profession. Specific areas include: self-awareness, emotional intelligence, communication, emotional management, wellness, and decision making. Students will learn strategies for navigating the dynamics of service organizations. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Navigate. Prer., Juniors and Seniors only. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

name: Mental Health Triage & First Aid
description: Intervention strategies and techniques for dealing with individual, group and organizational crises in a variety of settings will be explored. Types of crises include suicide, domestic violence, sexual assault/rape, school and community violence, military trauma, terrorism and natural disaster. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Co-Occurring Disorders and Trauma Informed Care
description: This class presents the basics of working with clients with co-occurring mental health and substance use disorders. The concept of trauma-informed care will be discussed in terms of practices incorporated into treatment with diverse populations. Course typically offered: Spring

name: The Science of Behavioral and Process Addictions
description: Many individuals experience addictive patterns of behavior, such as the overwhelming compulsion to engage in shopping, food, gambling, sex or exercise. This course will examine those Process Addictions and the power they have over many people. Meets with COUN 5900. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Fieldwork in Human Services II
description: Fieldwork is available on-campus and within the community. Site placement is coordinated through the Counseling and Human Services Department. Students must complete a field work orientation before enrolling, contact the department field work coordinator or instructor for more details. Prer, COUN 2950. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Summit. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Fieldwork in Human Services II
description: Fieldwork is available within the community. Site Placement coordinated through DCHS. Students must compile field work orientation before enrolling, contact the department fieldwork coordinator / instructor for details. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Summit. Prer., COUN 2950, COUN 3110, COUN 3500. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Clinical Supervision for Addictions Counselors
description: This course is designed to support addictions counselors as they learn models of supervision and tools necessary for supervision practice. Students will utilize motivational interviewing to facilitate effective supervision. Video recordings will be used to facilitate feedback. Prer., COUN 3600. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Introduction to Counseling and Human Services
description: Provides an overview of the field of counseling and human services. Students will learn about career opportunities in this field and the roles and functions of professional counselors in various settings. The history of the field and future trends will be presented.

name: Theories and Techniques of Individual Counseling
description: Major theories of individual counseling and their philosophic bases will be studied in this course. Techniques used in the application of theory to practice in counseling and consultation will be presented. Basic and advanced counseling skills will be introduced in this course and practiced in COUN  5020 taken concurrently. Prer., Admitted to counseling program.

name: Laboratory in Individual Counseling
description: Provides basic interviewing, influencing and counseling microskills and characteristics of counselors and counselees that impact the counseling process. Students engage in self-examination of characteristics that may affect them as professional counselors. Core counseling skills and competencies are practiced and refined. Prer., Must be admitted to the Masters in Counseling and Human Services program; COUN 5010.

name: Human Growth and Development
description: Provides a broad understanding of life span theories of human development; understanding of the nature and needs of individuals at all developmental levels; normal and abnormal human behavior indicators; personality theory and development; and learning theory with cultural contexts. Prer., Graduate students only.

name: Introduction to Play Therapy
description: Provides a developmental and systems approach to play therapy with content areas including history, theory, techniques, methods applications to special settings or populations. Also included is sand-play therapy which is based on the work of Jung.

name: Adventure Education and Experiential Learning
description: This training is designed for educators and community leaders wanting to develop and enhance their positive group facilitation skills and leadership strategies. This course will provide experiential ideas for developing group trust, enhancing teamwork, and encouraging cooperation. Meets with COUN 4070.

name: Spiritual Dimensions of Counseling
description: An experiential and analytic investigation of our spiritual dimension as persons, and of methods of assessment and intervention regarding spiritual and religious issues in counseling and psychotherapy. Prer., Graduate Students Only.

name: Theories & Techniques of Group Counseling
description: This course provides a comprehensive understanding of group development, stages, group dynamics, leadership styles and counseling theories across various settings. Core group facilitation skills and techniques will be studied in this course and practiced in COUN 5110. Prer., Must be admitted to the Masters in Counseling and Human Services program; COUN 5020.

name: Practicum in Professional Counseling
description: Provides students with experience in counseling and consultation. Introduces the counselor and client characteristics that may affect the counseling process. Students complete 100 clock hours of supervised field experience of which 40 hours must be in direct service to clients. Prer., COUN 5010, COUN 5020, COUN 5100, COUN 5110 and admission to CHS program.

name: Theories and Techniques of Relationship and Family Counseling
description: This course provides the student with a family systems approach emphasizing the foundational theories and techniques of marriage, family, couples, and relationship counseling. Students will learn to think systemically and gain awareness, insight and skills related to working with a multitude of family structures. Prer., Must be admitted to the Masters in Counseling and Human Services program; COUN 5010, 5020.

name: Laboratory in Marriage, Couples and Family Counseling
description: This course provides the student with marriage, couples and family counseling experiences as both a member and leader. Students will develop and apply systems counseling skills and techniques. Students engage in self-examination of family of origin and multigenerational family patterns.  Prer., Admission to DCHS, Coreq., COUN 5130.

name: Child & Adolescent Counseling
description: This course provides an exploration of counseling approaches to working with children and adolescents from a developmentally appropriate perspective. Topics: theories, counseling interventions, and strategies for children and adolescents, play therapy, cultural and ethical considerations when working with children and adolescents. Prer., COUN 5130 or consent of instructor.

name: Conflict Resolution Training
description: This workshop course presents a win-win approach to conflict resolution that can be utilized with individuals, families, groups and organizations. Participants will be asked to examine their personal conflict resolution strategies and change any win-lose strategies into win-win strategies. Prer., Open only to students enrolled in Counseling and Human Services program.

name: Executive and Leadership Coaching
description: This course is designed to enhance the skills of counseling students and Air Force Officers. When working with clients or Cadets to address personal issues, coaching skills can be utilized, once those issues have been addressed, as the next step in the process which can then propel the client or Cadet toward a path of success.

name: Psychology of the College Student
description: An orientation to developmental studies in personality, social and health domains of the college student. Focus is on age-related stresses and coping skills. Prer., Admission to the Counseling Program.

name: Advanced Seminar in Student Affairs
description: Taken during the final semester of the student’s program, requires the completion of an independent study on a topic of particular interest or concern to Student Affairs. The topic, and the method of conducting the study, will be mutually agreed upon by the faculty member and student. In-depth exploration of the topic will require the students to synthesize what they have learned in the program and demonstrate the ability to apply it. Prer., COUN 5060, COUN 5080, COUN 5190 admissions to the Counseling Program in Student Affairs.

name: Coaching and Consulting Practice
description: The course will outline theory and practice of professional coaching & consulting, including coaching knowledge, application, ethics, diversity, assessment procedures, advocacy & best practice guidelines. The course addresses coaching and consulting strategies for individuals, teams and organizations.

name: Practicum in Counseling and Leadership
description: Provides students with experience in counseling and leadership and introduces the counselor and client characteristics that may affect the counseling process. Students complete 100 clock hours of supervised field experience of which 40 hours must be in direct service to clients; the balance is indirect service. May be repeated 3 times. Prer., Concurrent with counseling core courses.

name: Advanced Techniques in Cadet Counseling
description: This course provides advanced training in specific counseling techniques for AOC’s. It includes detailed intervention plans for various issues relevant to the cadets at the Academy. Students develop a detailed case study in problem areas, visit local agencies and conduct a literature review of relevant adolescent issues. Prer., Admission to Counseling and Leadership Program.

name: College Student Development
description: This course reviews developmental theories related to both understanding and effectively counseling college age individuals. Students will examine personality, social and wellness domains of the developing college student. Specific topics related to specific developmental and psychological stressors for college age individuals will be addressed. Must be admitted to Counseling and Leadership. Prer., Successful completion of COUN and LEAD core classes.

name: Laboratory in Marriage, Couples, and Family Counseling
description: Provides students with skills in rapport building; information gathering and giving; structuring the session; reflecting and summarizing content and feeling; self disclosure; confrontation; and session closure for use in professional counseling sessions. Prer., Must be admitted to the Masters in Counseling and Human Services program; COUN 5010, COUN 5110, and COUN 5130.

name: Issues, Ethics and Trends in Professional  Counseling
description: This course covers professional roles and functions, goals and objectives, organizations and associations, preparation standards and credentialing, and history and trends in the counseling profession. Developing knowledge of the professional code of ethics, laws, and other guidelines related to the practice of professional counseling, and acquiring proficiency in making ethical decisions, will be emphasized.

name: Professional Ethics II
description: This course will provide participants with a comprehensive introduction to ethical and risk-management issues related to addiction treatment and services. It will focus on three key topics: 1) ethical dilemmas, 2) ethical decisions, and 3) risk-management concepts.

name: Adult Leadership Development
description: Explores the development of leadership, emphasizing entry level leadership skills for college-aged students. It surveys social and peer group influences, strategies for developing character, diversity issues and leading change in a college environment. Prer., Admission into the Counseling program.

name: Research in Counseling and Human Services
description: A comprehensive study of types of research, basic statistics, research project development, program evaluation, needs assessment, and ethical and legal considerations. A thorough review of the recent research literature in the student’s area of emphasis is required for this course. Prer., COUN  5010 and COUN  5020 or consent of instructor.

name: Measurement and Appraisal
description: This course provides a comprehensive study of educational and psychometric theories and approaches to appraisal, data collection and evaluation methods. Validity and reliability of instruments, psychometric statistics, variables influencing appraisal and interpretation of test results will be addressed. Ethical use of measurement instruments, multicultural considerations, and strategies for consultation will be included. Prer., Must be admitted to the Masters in Counseling and Human Services program.

name: Career Development
description: This course offers a comprehensive study of career development theories; sources for obtaining occupational, educational, and labor market information; relational, cultural, and other factors that affect career development; assessment tools, techniques, and program development for career counseling, guidance, and education, and for lifestyle and career decision making, including applications for special groups and diverse populations.

name: Advanced Psychopathology and Diagnosis
description: An intensive survey of the major theories, research findings and behavioral characteristics associated with mental illness and behavior disorders. Requires thorough working knowledge of the DSM IV and related diagnostic tools. Prer., Must be admitted to the Masters in Counseling and Human Services program or AOC program or consent of instructor.

name: Advanced Play Therapy
description: Builds on the basic concepts presented in Introduction to Play Therapy and includes using play to help children and families communicate through symbols, metaphors and stories. Puppet play, the hero/heroine’s journey, family art and games are highlighted. Prer., COUN 5050 or consent of instructor.

name: Principles of Addiction Treatment
description: This course examines the etiology of addiction; various models and effective treatment methods supported by current research. Assessment of co-occurring disorders and addiction counselor competencies will be investigated and applied to adults and adolescents.

name: Infectious Diseases in Addiction Treatment
description: This course examines the complex relationship between a client’s use of substances, lifestyle choices, and physiological health. Assess the importance of disease screening, exploring client risk, and educating clients about disease prevention. Prer., Graduate Students Only or consent of instructor.

name: Motivational Interviewing I & II
