description: This course examines the data security and privacy laws and regulations that govern the collection, use, storage, and destruction of sensitive information. An understanding of these laws can help a cybersecurity expert understand how organizations can implement a program that will minimize legal and business risks. Students enrolled in this course will also learn about the nature of cybercrime, methods of investigating cybercrime, securing the crime scene, and collecting evidence of cybercrime. Students will explore the challenges involved with international cooperation in pursuing cybercrime offenders, and problems of enforcement between different international legal systems. Prer., Graduate business students only.

name: Intro to Space Cybersecurity for Managers
description: Space systems and infrastructure are susceptible to cyber vulnerabilities. This course focuses on protection and risk mitigation for malicious cyber activities against space assets, identification of attack vectors, and vulnerabilities to space systems. Students apply cybersecurity principles to the space domain and learn best practices for sustaining a secure cyber environment throughout the space mission lifecycle. Emphasis is on practical applications for real-world space mission scenarios. Recommended: CYSM 6100 or cybersecurity certification/experience. Prer., Graduate business students only. Meets with SPMG 6600.

name: Research Seminar in Information Security Management
description: This course examines the philosophical and theoretical foundations of information systems security. The focus is on understanding distinctive research orientations regarding information security in organizations. The goal of the course is to provide an intellectual foundation for students to develop an appropriate research program in this area. Prer., CYSM 6200, CYSM 6300, QUAN 7110. DBA Students only.

name: Research Seminar in Information Privacy
description: This course examines the privacy issues regarding information systems. The focus is on understanding distinctive research orientations regarding information privacy. Discussions will emphasize critical evaluation of theoretical foundations of privacy in our modern technologically based society. The goal of the course is to provide an intellectual foundation for students to develop an appropriate research program in this area. Prer., CYSM 6100, QUAN 7110. DBA students only.

name: Research Project
description: This course focuses on developing a conceptual paper in an area of interest in information security or privacy. It aims to provide students with a mentored, structured approach to develop critical skills required for dissertation. Students will apply the concepts, theories and methods learned in various courses. The paper may include plan for data collection and analysis. This preliminary research paper can serve as a basis for the dissertation proposal. Prer., CYSM 7120, CYSM 7130. DBA students only.

name: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is designed to guide students through various stages of the dissertation process beginning with the development of a proposal and ending with a successful dissertation defense. Students may repeat this course to meet the necessary requirements. Prer., Instructor approval (program director or dissertation chair).

name: Continuing Doctoral Dissertation
description: Continuing Doctoral Dissertation. Prer., Instructor approval (program director or dissertation chair).

name: Independent Study in Cybersecurity Management- Undergraduate
description: Independent study in Cybersecurity Management at the undergraduate level given with the consent of the instructor who directs the study and the dean. Prer., Junior/senior standing only and consent of instructor and dean.

name: Candidate for Degree
description: Candidate for Degree. Prer., EDBA Graduate Status.

name: Dance Appreciation: From Ballet to Beyoncé
description: This introductory course focuses on the role of dance as part of human identity. How does dance affect you? How do different cultures use dance to communicate, express, protest, and celebrate? How does dance intersect with visual arts, music, theater? Approved for LAS Humanities area requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore- Arts, Humanities, and Cultures.

name: Fundamentals of Dance Technique
description: An introduction to dance technique. Students will focus on technique exercises, stretching, body alignment, choreography, and movement explorations. The course is a beginning dance class and the foundation for other dance classes. Additional outside work required. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Arts, Humanities, and Cultures.

name: Modern Dance I
description: The class is designed to provide a foundation of modern dance technique. Students will experience full dance classes consisting of warm-up, technique exercises, stretching, body alignment, center exercises and cool down. Students will also participate in movement explorations through improvisation.. Additional outside work required. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Explore-Arts, Humanities, and Cultures. Prer., DNCE 2700 or consent of instructor.

name: Ballet I
description: Introduces the basic techniques of ballet, which are built upon knowledge of ballet terminology, fundamental exercises, and the basic elements of  dance. Focuses on movement-oriented dance, comprised of stretching, barre warm-up exercises, simple terre a terre and jumping steps, and basic extended positions. Additional outside work required. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Explore-Arts, Humanities, and Cultures. Prer., DNCE 2700 or consent of instructor.

name: Afro-Brazilian Dances
description: Studio course that introduces the movement vocabulary, cultural, and social aspects of specific styles of Afro-Brazilian Dances: Jongo, Côco de Roda, Caboclinhos, and Orixá Dances. Readings, video viewing, writing, and in-class creative projects will inform the main focus of the course, movement exploration. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Inclusiveness (Global/Diversity).

name: Special Topics in Dance Technique
description: Focus is on various forms of dance. Each semester the course will use technique, research, and performance to highlight a specific dance genre. For both beginners and advanced. No prerequisites for this course.

name: Topics in Early Dance History
description: The course explores special topics related to the history of dance ranging from ancient times to  the end of the 19th century. The course examines key topics in Western theatrical dance history as well as Transnational forms. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Writing Intensive. Prer., DNCE 2700.

name: Topics in Contemporary Dance History:
description: The course explores special topics related to modern and postmodern history of dance, mainly from the 20th century. The course examines key topics in Western theatrical dance history as well as Transnational forms. Prer., DNCE 2700.

name: Dance Performance Practicum
description: Students will receive practical experience as a dancer in a project approved by the program. Enrollment by audition and/or permission of instructor. Prer., DNCE 2700 or consent of instructor.

name: Dance Technical Practicum
description: Students will receive practical experience as a technician in a project approved by the program. Enrollment by audition and/or permission of instructor. Prer., DNCE 2700 or consent of instructor.

name: Dance Choreography Practicum
description: Students will receive practical experience as a choreographer or assistant choreographer in a project approved by the program. Enrollment by audition and/or permission of instructor. Prer., DNCE 2700 or consent of instructor.

name: Special Topics in Dance Technique
description: Focus is on various forms of dance. Each semester the course will use technique, research, and performance to highlight a specific dance genre. Prer., DNCE 2700 or THTR 2700.  Meets with THTR 3700.

name: Advanced Modern Dance
description: The class is designed for dancers who are at an intermediate to advanced level in modern dance technique and is a continuation of DNCE 3710. Students will participate in movement explorations where they can creatively engage the fundamentals of space, time and force through improvisation. The course will culminate in a modern dance performance. Additional outside work required. Prer., DNCE 2700, DNCE 3710, or consent of instructor.

name: Jazz Dance Technique
description: Introduces the basic techniques of jazz dance, which are built upon knowledge of jazz terminology, rhythm, fundamental exercises, and the basic elements of dance. The course will culminate in a jazz dance performance. Additional outside work required. Prer., DNCE 2700 or consent of instructor.

name: Tap Dance
description: An introduction to the basic techniques of tap dance that progresses through intermediate and advanced terminology. In addition to performance, the class considers tap history and its position as an American art form. Prer., DNCE 2700.

name: Hip Hop
description: This course explores specific technique, vocabulary, creative processes, musicality and dynamics of hip hop. Styles include dancing, locking, popping, hip hop and house techniques, as well as historical contexts. Prer., DNCE 2700.

name: Samba
description: Samba is an umbrella term that encompasses different Afro-Brazilian dances. This studio course introduces the movement vocabulary, cultural, and social aspects of specific styles of Samba. Readings, video viewing, writing, and in-class creative projects will inform movement exploration. Prer., DNCE 2770 or DNCE 2700.

name: Contemporary Styles: Jazz, Lyrical, and Modern Dance
description: With a particular emphasis on jazz, lyrical, and modern styles, this course considers a range of contemporary dance techniques and assesses their overlaps and influences on one another. The course culminates in a presentation. Prer., DNCE 2700.

name: Dance Capstone
description: Students will receive practical experience in a culminating project that will be adjudicated by the Theatre and Dance faculty. Enrollment by audition and/or permission of instructor. Prer., DNCE 2700 or consent of instructor.

name: Dance Composition I
description: Students will study and apply the basic choreographic elements that go into creating an original dance. In a laboratory type setting, students will work on developing their own artistic voices through short movement compositions as well as give critique to others. Additional outside work required. Prer., DNCE 2700 or consent of instructor.

name: Dance Composition 2
description: Students study and apply advanced choreographic elements that go into creating an original dance. Building on level one composition, this culminating course ends with a dance showcase. Prer., DNCE 4700.

name: Modern Dance II
description: Building on modern dance foundations, this class introduces dancers to advance principles and exercises. Students will participate in movement explorations where they can creatively engage the fundamentals of space, time and force through improvisation. Culminates in a modern dance performance. Additional outside work required. Prer., DNCE 2720.

name: Ballet II
description: Building on ballet foundations, this class introduces dancers to advanced ballet principles and exercises intended to develop harmony, stylistic specificity and artistry. Excerpts from the classical repertoire will be used to promote musicality and artistic expression. Prer., DNCE 3740.

name: Spec Tpcs in Music and Dance:
description: Through the study of historical and contemporary convergences across music, sound, dance and movement, students will develop collaborative languages and methods in order to build and articulate original works. Topics will vary each semester. Prer., DNCE 2700 or consent of instructor. Meets with MUS 4900.

name: Introduction Data Analytics and Systems Engineering
description: Introduction to data analytics and systems engineering. Basic methods used for descriptive, predictive and diagnostic data analysis. Engineering complex systems. Exploring the importance of collecting, understanding and analyzing data in engineering complex systems using simple robotic systems.

name: Introduction to Statistics for Data Analytics
description: Introduction to statistics for data analytics using R Studio and SPSS. Includes basic statistics, distributions, statistical tests, variance and hypothesis testing (t-, chi^2, F tests), and ANOVA, an introduction to descriptive and predictive analytics and linear probability mixed models. Prer., CS 1120 or ECE 1021 or instructor permission (equivalent programming experience required). Meets with CS 2020.

name: Computer Based Modeling in C
description: Emphasis on algorithm development and H/W implementation of C programs for solving engineering problems. Students learn to write structured C programs using: arrays, user functions, pointers, data structures, file 1/0 and multi-file compiles. Meets with ECE 2021.

name: Advanced Robotics
description: Explore advanced robotics topics through the project management process. Project based class with scheduled milestones, min. lecture, max. applied. For the final project, each student will build and program a small autonomous vehicle to navigate between GPS coordinates. Prer., ECE 2021 or DASE 2021 or Permission of Instructor. Meets with ECE 3003.

name: C++ & GUI Programming
description: A hands-on course in C++ programming and GUI development integrating hardware and software. Students implement programs on a Raspberry Pi with a Touchscreen. Basic computer architecture and the Linux OS are covered. Min. lecture, max. applied. Prer., DASE 2021 or ECE 2021 or ECE 1021 or Permission of Instructor. Meets with ECE 3005.

name: Python & Jupyter Programming
description: A hands-on course in Python programming and Jupyter Notebook development using various add-on libraries; integrating hardware and software. Students implement programs on a Raspberry Pi with a touch screen. Basic computer architecture and the Linux OS are covered. Min. lecture, max. applied. Prer., DASE 2021 or ECE 2021 or ECE 1021 or Permission of Instructor. Meets with ECE 3007.

name: IoT on AWS
description: A hands-on course in Amazon Web Services (AWS) Internet of Things (loT) programming; integrating hardware and software. Students initiate programs on a Raspberry Pi, through AWS, to different types of loT devices. Min. lecture, max. applied. Prer., ECE 1021 or ECE 2021 or DASE 2021 or Permission of Instructor. Meets with ECE 3009.

name: Introduction to Operations Research
description: An introduction to quantitative modeling methods (i.e., mathematical programming, optimization, queuing, simulation, decision analysis) with broad application. The course focuses on the computer implementation of models, and the application of models to practical decision-making scenarios. Prer., CS 2300 or MATH 3130; ECE 3610 or MATH 3810; DASE students only.

name: Introduction to Systems Engineering
description: Introduction to the systems engineering process to include systems in engineering methods, lifecycle models, risk management, and tradeoff analysis. Focus is on the role of the systems engineer throughout a project, with emphasis on both the technical and project management roles. Prer., Senior standing, DASE students only.

name: Data Mining
description: This course covers introduction to fundamental concepts, data warehousing, data pre-processing, association rules, cluster analysis, classification and prediction. Prer., CS 4420 or 5420. Meets with CS 4435.

name: Intelligent Robotics
description: This course introduces students to the field of robotics.  Topics include Robotics Operating System, Agents and agent-based system, swarm intelligence, Unmanned Vehicles (UGV, UAV, AUV), robot teaming, mission planning/management systems, path planning & obstacle avoidance. Prer., CS 2060, CS 2150 or MATH 2150, MATH 1360, CS 1450, and CS 2300 or MATH 3130. Meets with CS 4460.

name: Data Visualization
description: Animation: basic principles, physically based modeling, algorithms for animation, constraint optimization, use of dynamics in animations, and teleological modeling. Scientific Visualization: overview, foundational techniques, and applications. Prer., CS 2300 or MATH 3130, CS 4720, or instructor consent. Meets with CS 4470.

name: Computer-based Optimization
description: Computer-Based optimization techniques including simulation, modeling, heuristic methods, genetic algorithms, simulated annealing, duality theory, dynamic programming, and queuing theory. Prer., ECE 1021 or CS 1450. Meets with CS 4570.

name: Evolutionary Computation
description: Introduction to evolutionary computation with emphasis on genetic algorithms. Includes evolution strategies, evolutionary programming, schemata fitness functions and classifiers, current research topics, messy algorithms, adaptive landscapes. Prer., ECE 3610 or MATH 3810 or QUAN 2010; CS 3160; CS 4720 or CS 4820; or Instructor Permission.  Meets with CS 4710 and CS 5710.

name: Machine Learning
description: Introduction to machine learning followed by a selection of machine learning topics such as regression, Bayesisan learning, Hidden Markov Models, support vector machine, clustering and reinforcement learning. Prer., CS 4820; MATH 2150; MATH 3130 or CS 2300; CS 3160 or instructor consent. Meets with CS 4860/5860.

name: Design of Experiments
description: An introduction to experimentation and the application of statistical design. Topics include design and analysis of single-factor and multi-factor experiments. Prer., MATH 3810 or ECE 3610.

name: The Economics of Social Issues
description: The Economics of Social Issues introduces the student to economics in a less rigorous manner than ECON 1010. Economic issues are introduced in examining wealth, poverty, energy, crime, education, health, discrimination, unemployment and inflation. May not be taken for credit by students who have already completed ECON 3010. Approved for LAS Social Science area requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Society, Health and Behavior. GT-SS1.

name: Introduction to Microeconomics
description: An analysis of the market system and its role in allocating goods and services; problems of market failure (e.g., monopoly, environmental pollution, and public goods), and alternative government responses to such problems. Approved for LAS Social Science area requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Society, Health and Behavior.

name: Economics in Practice
description: Designed as a practical introduction to the process of teaching and learning economics through activity-based economic instruction. Covers a variety of economic topics by use of materials developed by National Council on Economic Education. While particularly relevant to prospective teachers of K-12 economics, the class is open to anyone wishing a hands-on approach to economic content. Approved for LAS Social Science area requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Society, Health and Behavior. GT-SS1. Prer., Not open to students who have completed ECON 3010 or ECON 3020.

name: Survey of Economics
description: An introduction to basic economic principles and problems of contemporary society.  Surveys the fundamentals of private enterprise and the economic role of government in society.  Not eligible for credit if ECON 3010 already completed.

name: Economics for Leaders
description: This course introduces basic economics concepts and tools of economic reasoning and applies them within the context of public issues and economic development. Participants receive direct instruction from economists, participate in group activities, presentations, simulations, and discussions.

name: Economic Forces in American History
description: This course introduces and applies economic concepts and tools of economic reasoning to pivotal events in history. Participants hear lectures from economic historians, participate in group activities, simulations, and discussions.

name: Entrepreneurship in the Global Economy
description: The course focuses on the introduction and application of basic economic concepts and economic reasoning skills to entrepreneurship. The goal of this program is to prepare students to apply economic concepts and economic reasoning to starting a business.

name: The Environment and the Economy
description: This course focuses on the introduction of basic economic concepts and economic reasoning skills and their application to the environment. The goal of this program is to present topics on environmental issues and concerns and let them apply the lens of economics to discover how incentives and institutions influence decision-makers. Participants receive direct instruction, participate in group activities, presentations, simulations and discussions to improve their own understanding of current local, national and global environmental issues. Their culminating project involves using economic concepts to analyze a current environmental issue and then proposing a public policy that could improve the outcomes.

name: Introduction to Macroeconomics
description: This course provides an examination of the forces that determine national income, unemployment, and inflation; the efforts of the government and the central bank to manage the state of the macroeconomy; and, the influence of the global economy on domestic macroeconomic functioning. Approved for LAS Social Science area requirement. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Society, Health and Behavior. Prer., ECON 1010 or consent of instructor.

name: Personal Economics
description: Students will learn to apply the economic way of thinking to manage their scarce resources. Employs economic concepts to understand: financial planning and income management; saving and investing; stocks, bonds, and mutual funds; risk-return tradeoff and diversification; interest rates and credit. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Society, Health and Behavior.

name: Statistics for Economics
description: Uses of descriptive and inferential statistics in economics. Introduction to probability, random sampling, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing and simple linear regression.

name: Intermediate Microeconomic Theory
description: Production, price, and distribution theory under conditions of perfect and imperfect competition. Prer., ECON 1010 or ECON 1050 with a “C” or better.

name: Intermediate Macroeconomic Theory
description: Keynesian, classical, and monetarist theories of national income determination. Problems of unemployment, inflation, international exchange, and growth. Prer., ECON 2020 with a “C” or better.

name: History of Economic Thought
description: Surveys the main schools of economic thought from the pre-cursors to the Classical economists through the modern neo-Classical reconciliation. The challenges posed by the Marxian critique and the Keynesian transformation will be considered.  Approved for LAS Social Science area requirement. Prer., ECON 2020 with a “C” or better.

name: Austrian Economics
description: This course surveys the conceptual analysis of the Austrian School in economics. Topics include the Austrian School perspective on: market process, profit and loss, entrepreneurship, spontaneous order, money, inflation, recession, knowledge, competition, and economic progress. Prer., ECON 1010 with a “C” or better or consent of instructor.

name: Public Sector Economics
description: This course aims to explore government intervention in the economy, examining the impact of expenditure programs and taxation on citizens. It thoroughly covers the theoretical foundations guiding government involvement, current public finance issues, empirical evaluation of policies, and considers the justification for such intervention. Prer., ECON 1010 or ECON 1050 with a “C” or better.

name: International Political Economy
description: Overview of the world political economy, especially in the post-WWII period. The central goal of the course is to provide information and develop analytical tools necessary for students to grasp the political issues inherent in international economic relations. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Sustainability. Prer., ECON 1000, ECON 1010 or ECON 2020 with a “C” or better. Meets with PSC 4280.

name: Environmental Economics
description: Application of economic analysis to environmental and natural resources issues and policies. Topics include: benefit-cost analysis, property rights, depletable resources, energy resources, toxic substances, air and water pollution. Prer., ECON 1010 with a “C” or better or permission of instructor.

name: Ecological Economics
description: Applies new knowledge in natural and physical sciences and behavior to all economic resources: labor, capital, and natural resources. Uses new analytical tools such as systems thinking and path dependency along with neoclassical analysis. Emphasizes sustainable development, not economic growth. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Sustainability. Prer., ECON 1010 or ECON 1050 with a “C” or better or consent of instructor.

name: International Economics
description: Analysis of the basis for and consequences of opening an economy to the international arena. Specific issues considered are the benefits and costs of international trade, the reason for barriers to trade, the determination of exchange rates and the effect of government policies of international good and factor flows. Prer., ECON 2020 with a “C” or better.

name: Economic History of the United States
description: American economic organization and institutions and their development from colonial times to the present. Prer., ECON 2020 with a “C” or better. Meets with HIST 3650.

name: Topics in Global Economic History
description: This course and its variants explore the economic history of non-US regions, such as, but not limited to, Latin America, Europe, Africa and Asia, in a seminar setting. It is designed to be an application of micro and macroeconomic concepts. Prer., ECON 2020 or instructor consent.

name: Globalization
description: Globalization is studied as part of an exchange of technology, goods, and financial markets. The exchanges of goods, services, and ideas across national borders are pervasive. Communication systems help this process, but also help those who resist globalization to better articulate and organize their viewpoints. Approved for LAS Global Awareness requirement. Prer., Sophomore standing. Meets with PSC 4590.

name: Industrial Organization
description: Examines the application of economic theory to business behavior, strategy, and market structure. Prer., ECON 1010 or ECON 1050 with a “C” or better.

name: Comparative Economic Systems
description: An examination of the underlying economic logic and relative advantages/disadvantages of differing economic systems. Special attention is paid to market-based economies, planned economies, Islamic economies, and shareholder economic systems. Approved for LAS Social Science area and Global Awareness requirements. Prer., ECON 2020 with a “C” or better.

name: East Asian Economic Growth
description: The economic transformation of East Asia since the end of the Second World War brought unprecedented sustained economic growth to a significant share of the global population. This course explores the historical roots and methods of this transformation and explores the current challenges facing this region. Particular emphasis is given to the economies and economic transition of Japan, the Republic of Korea, and the People’s Republic of China. Prer., ECON 2020 or instructor consent.

name: Economics of South Asia
description: This course will provide students with an understanding of the how economic issues within South Asia have evolved in the post-colonial period. Topics include the role of the state in post-colonial economic development and a concern with industrialization, technical change and development of human capital; the impact of patron-client relationships on economic performance, agriculture and environment; globalization, economic reform and poverty and income inequality. Prer., ECON 2020 or instructor consent.

name: Economic Development
description: Explores the nature and sources of improvement in the standard of living in a nation or region. Among the issues addressed are the measurement of development, the role of government, gender implications of development, and environmental and economic sustainability. Local, regional, and international issues are addressed. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Sustainability. Prer., ECON 1010 or ECON 2020 with a “C” or better.

name: The Economics of US Professional Sport
description: The Investigation of the economics of professional US sport through presentation, lecture and Discussion. Prer., ECON 1010 or ECON 1050.

name: Law and Economics
description: Examines how economic theory has been applied in legal theory and been used to shape legal outcomes. Numerous cases are examined. Prer., ECON 1010 or ECON 1050 with a “C” or better.

name: Behavioral Economics
description: Behavioral Economics explores the challenge to traditional models of economics offered by the work of economists and social scientists such as Daniel Kahneman. By exploring the role that social framing, personal psychology, and emotional responses play in economics decisions, the limits of traditional economic theory is explored and extensions to traditional theory considered. Prer., ECON 1010 or ECON 1050 with a “C” or better.

name: Special Topics in Economics
description: A study of special topics in economics. Topics vary from semester to semester and generally emphasize the application of economic analysis to current issues. Prer., ECON 1010 or ECON 1050.

name: Advanced Microeconomic Theory
description: Study of the core of microeconomic theory using calculus. Topics include: consumer theory of the firm, profit maximization, efficiency and market failure. Several advanced topics from recent developments in microeconomics are also examined. Prer., ECON 3010 with a “C” or better, and MATH 1120 or MATH 1350, or consent of instructor.

name: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory
description: Study of the core of macroeconomic theory using calculus. Topics include Keynesian vs. Classical economic models, macroeconomic growth models, open economy macroeconomics, and macroeconomic policy analysis. Prer., ECON 3020 with a “C” or better or consent of instructor.

name: Urban Economics
description: Economic analysis of why cities exist, where they develop, how they grow, and how different activities are arranged within cities. Explores the economics of urban problems such as: poverty, congestion, pollution, and crime. Prer., ECON 1010 or ECON 1050 with a “C” or better.

name: International Trade Policy
description: Uses various models to analyze why countries trade, how and why they restrict trade, with a focus on US trade policy. Studies international trade agreement and disputes at bilateral and multilateral levels, with an emphasis on WTO. Prer., ECON 3010 with a “C” or better.

name: Decision and Game Theory
description: An introduction to decision theory and game theory. No mathematical knowledge beyond high school algebra is assumed. Theoretical development of decision theory and game theory will be coupled with application of both to practice and the real world. See course schedule for topics covered. Prer., ECON 1010 or PSC 3500 or PHIL 1120 or PHIL 3420. Meets with PSC 4440 and PHIL 4440.

name: Money and Banking
description: The study of the interaction between financial markets and the Federal Reserve Banking system. Emphasizes the conduct of monetary policy to encourage economic growth and stability. Topics include interest rates, inflation, the money supply and the influence of these variables on the business cycle. Not available for credit to students who have completed FNCE 4500. Coreq., ECON 3020 or instructor consent.

name: Constitution and the Economy
description: Considers the economic role of government expressed in the Constitution and in Supreme Court opinions. Emphasis is on liberty, efficiency, and prosperity. Special topics include: police power, takings, commerce clause, and substantive due process. Prer., ECON 1010 or ECON 1050.

name: Economic Freedom
description: Examines the philosophy of individual liberty as a basis for the study of normative (or welfare) economics. The course considers theory, application, and critiques. Topics include: constitutional foundations, efficiency, spontaneous order, index of economic freedom, and contemporary policy issues. Prer., ECON 1010 or ECON 1050.

name: Power and Prosperity
description: Uses three books by Mancur Olson to study the economic prosperity of nations. Considers whether Olson’s work presents a dynamic theory of political economy. Topics include: free rider behavior, economics of interest groups, rent seeking, and socially-contrived markets. Prer., ECON 1010 or ECON 1050.

name: Introduction to Econometrics
description: Development and application of multiple regression techniques in testing economic theories. Prer., ECON 3010 or ECON 3020, ECON 2810 with a “C” or better or consent of instructor.

name: Senior Seminar
description: Required of all economics majors. This course provides an opportunity for economics majors to demonstrate the ability to access existing economic theory and evidence, apply existing theories and evidence to issues of current economic interest, and develop written assessments of issues of current economic interest in a seminar setting. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Summit. Prer., ECON 2810, ECON 3010, and ECON 3020 with a “C” or better.

name: Economics for Educators
description: Learn about scarcity, gains from trade, marginal decision making, supply and demand, profits and competition, property rights, money and monetary stability, and sources of economic growth. Brief coverage of personal decision-making including career choice, saving, investing, and wise use of credit. Prer., Undergraduate degree and current K-12 teacher.

name: Methods for Teaching Economics
description: Presents activity based economics materials and methods to prepare the secondary-level teacher to teach economics. Prer., ECON 5010.

name: Methods for Teaching Secondary Financial Literacy
description: Methods for Teaching Secondary Financial Literacy focuses on the fundamentals of economic reasoning as applied to financial literacy. In this course, the tools of economics are applied to the individual management of scarcity. Topics covered include financial planning and income management; savings and investment; stocks, bonds and mutual funds; risk-return trade-off; and interest rates and credit. Teachers will be guided in the selection of grade appropriate materials.

name: Teaching Personal Financial Literacy in Elementary Grades
description: Course provides the content, methods, and materials necessary for elementary teachers to deliver personal financial literacy using economic reasoning. Topics covered include earning income, saving, spending, credit, and money management.

name: Teaching Economics
description: The seminar will explore a variety of topics applicable to the study and teaching of economics. The emphasis will be on themes, topics and strategies most appropriate to motivate students’ interest in economics. Courses offered through the Colorado Council on Economic Education. Not an option for ECON majors or grad students. Meets with ECON 6320 and MATH 6310.

name: Personal Economics for Teachers
description: These seminars explore a variety of topics applicable to the study and teaching of personal economics. The emphasis is on themes, topics and strategies most appropriate to motivate students’ interest in personal economics and financial literacy. Courses are offered in conjunction with the Colorado Council on Economic Education. Meets with ECON 6310.

name: Economics for Teachers
description: This course provides content, pedagogy, and materials for teaching a semester high school economics course. Topics covered include scarcity, cost, incentives, labor, entrepreneurship, property rights, money and inflation, role of government, and international trade.

name: Economics Issues for Teachers
description: This course provides content, pedagogy, and materials for incorporating economics content and analysis into high school history, social studies, and current events lessons and classroom activities. Topics include the fall of the Soviet Union, issues in international trade, water use and the environment, and world poverty and development.

name: Economic Forces in American History
description: This course provides content, pedagogy, and materials for incorporating economic concepts and reasoning in high school American history courses. Participants will hear lectures from economic historians and participate in classroom simulations designed to accompany topics from the colonial to the modern era.

name: Institute on the Environment and the Economy
description: This course introduces secondary teachers and curriculum specialists to the use of economic reasoning and analysis in environmental studies through lectures, case studies, and simulations that can be readily integrated into classroom studies of historical and contemporary environmental issues.

name: The Economic Demise of the Soviet Union - Online for Teachers
description: Provides content, pedagogy, and materials for incorporating economic content and reasoning skills into the study of the rise and fall of the Soviet Union. Concepts addressed within context of Soviet history include scarcity, choice, cost, incentives, property rights, and transaction cost.

name: Economics Online for Teachers: Fundamental Principles and Markets
description: Provides content, pedagogy, and materials for teaching a semester high school economics course. Topics covered include scarcity, choice, opportunity cost, marginal analysis, incentives, markets, supply, demand, equilibrium price, labor markets.

name: Economics Online for Teachers: Institutions, Government, and the Economy
description: Provides content, pedagogy, and materials for teaching a semester high school economics course. Topics covered include entrepreneurship, innovation, property rights, money and banking, money supply and monetary policy, government, public choice, and international trade.

name: Economics of Disasters Online for Teachers
description: Provides content, pedagogy, and materials for incorporating economic content and reasoning skills into history and current events. Study includes role of government, markets, and non-profit institutions in historical and contemporary disasters.

name: Economic Forces in American History Online: Colonialism to Early 20th Century
description: Economic History Online for Teachers (EHOFT) incorporates the tools of economic reasoning into the study of history and provides secondary school teachers background in basic economics through direct instruction and practice in historical case study analysis.

name: Economic Forces in American History Online: Early 20th Century to the Present
description: U.S. Economic History for Teachers, Part 2 is the second of a two-course series designed to introduce fundamental economic reasoning tools to secondary history teachers so that they can confidently incorporate economic analysis into U.S history lessons.

name: Economics Internship
description: Freq: Fall, Spring, Summer. A supervised learning experience in the private, non-profit, or public sector. Enrollment dependent on availability of suitable placement opportunities. Prer., Junior standing, consent of instructor and department chair.

name: Independent Study in Economics
description: Independent Study in Economics

name: Independent Study in Macroeconomics
description: Independent Study in Macroeconomics

name: Undergraduate Research - Independent Study
description: Provides an opportunity to conduct research with Economics faculty and graduate students by one or more students on topics determined by a faculty member. Prer., Consent of instructor required.

name: Independent Study in Economics
description: Independent Study in Economics

name: Introduction to Inclusive Education
description: This course introduces the history, theoretical foundations, the law, and an introduction to programmatic designs to meet the broad range of needs of all young children. Includes 15 hours of fieldwork in local inclusive classrooms. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Intro to Educational Psychology
description: Provides teachers with the knowledge of psychology most relevant to teaching. The focus is on areas of child development and major learning theories and their application in the classroom.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Introduction to Technology in Education
description: This course explores the foundations, strategies, and tools for using technology as a means of engaging all students within inclusive educational settings. A focus is placed on universal design for learning (UDL) as a framework for selecting, evaluating, and implementing educational technology. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Children’s Literature
description: This course is an introduction to children’s literature. Students will read a variety of genres, explore issues related to children’s literature, and engage in a significant amount of responsive and evaluative writing. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Inclusiveness (Global/Diversity); Explore-Arts, Humanities, and Cultures; Writing Intensive. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Health and Physical Education for Educators
description: This course provides an overview of physical education and health standards, with specific attention to how they are addressed in the elementary school curriculum. Instructional strategies are explored for the integration of movement and health concepts into other content areas. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Arts Integration for Educators
description: This course will focus on methods and materials for teaching visual art and music as they relate to the growth and development of children. Emphasis will be on curriculum, methods, and strategies for prospective K-6 classroom teachers. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Integrated Social Studies I
description: This course will provide an overview of United States geography, history, political science, economics, sociology, and anthropology. The main goals of this course are to provide students with an understanding of past and current events in the United States through the lens of multiple social sciences and to increase awareness of the connection of past events to our current society.

name: Integrated Science I
description: This course introduces the exploration of major connecting themes in life sciences, earth science, and physical science. Concepts covered explore science topics through discussion, demonstrations, inquiry activities, hands-on laboratory activities, readings, and presentations. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Sustainability. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Integrated Science II
description: This course expands upon the major themes in  life sciences, earth science, and physical science introduced in IELM 2000. Concepts covered explore science topics through discussion, demonstrations, inquiry activities, hands-on laboratory activities, readings, and presentations. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Schools, Society, and Diversity
description: Emphasizing the foundations of American education through a contemporary lens, the course investigates multiple dimensions of diversity and society impacting today’s schools. Implications for innovative educational curricula and pedagogy are explored. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Society, Health and Behavior, and Writing Intensive. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: English as a Second Language for Educators
description: Presents current and emerging philosophies, theories,and methods on teaching literacy and content areas to culturally and linguistically diverse students. Open to juniors/seniors only. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Early School Diversity Practicum
description: Provides early school diversity experiences for potential teachers in public school classrooms. This experience focuses on the roles, responsibilities and qualities of the professional teacher through practical experience. Open to juniors/seniors only. Can be repeated for up to 3 credits. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Introduction to Professional Year - Inclusive Early Childhood
description: All UCCS students wishing to enter the IECE Professional Year must submit a packet of request materials. This course also includes support professional self-reflection, resources for developing a professional resume and for passing the Praxis exams. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory only. Coreq., IECE 4035. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Introduction to Professional Year - Elementary
description: All UCCS students wishing to enter the Elementary Professional Year must submit a packet of request materials. Materials will be submitted online via the campus LMS. Successful completion of this course is prerequisite to all other Professional Year course work and field work. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Introduction to Professional Year - Secondary
description: All UCCS students wishing to enter the Secondary Professional Year must submit a packet of request materials. Materials will be submitted online via the campus LMS. Successful completion of this course is prerequisite to all other Professional Year course work and field work. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Elementary Curriculum, Instruction, and Classroom Management
description: Principles of curriculum design, instructional models and practice, standards-based curriculum and assessment, planning, organization, and classroom management and discipline. Prer., EDUC 3900, SPED 3001, or SPED 5001. Course typically offered: Summer

name: Secondary Classroom Management
description: This course will explore the importance of establishing a positive structured learning environment by developing a successful classroom management model, and will provide a comprehensive knowledge base concerning the two main strands of instructional and behavior management. Prer., EDUC 3900, Acceptance into TELP. Course typically offered: Summer

name: Teaching Reading and Writing in the Content Area
description: Designed to help secondary teachers become aware of the reading and writing process and how they apply to subject matter material. Emphasizes a framework for functionally teaching reading and writing within a particular content area and strategies for increasing student independence with print. Prer., EDUC 4600. Course typically offered: Summer

name: Differentiating Instruction for Secondary Teachers: Teaching to Meet the Needs of All Learners
description: Participants will build a foundation of understanding from which they will develop skills, strategies, and resources that they can then apply in their teaching to address the complex challenges of meeting the diverse learning needs of all students. Prer., EDUC 4600. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Secondary Curriculum, Instruction and Evaluation
description: Students develop an understanding of the context in which instruction takes place in today’s middle and high schools, as well as principles of curriculum design, including standards-based lesson and unit planning. Methods of assessment, interpretation of results, and diagnostic teaching will be addressed. Prer., EDUC 4600. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Secondary English Methods
description: Secondary English Methods gives an overview of instructional theory, methods, and materials in English and helps the students develop teaching strategies and address the Colorado model content standards. Prer., EDUC 4600. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Secondary Social Studies Methods
description: Secondary Social Studies Methods gives an overview of instructional theory, methods, and materials in social studies and helps students develop teaching strategies and address the Colorado model content standard. Prer., EDUC 4600.

name: Secondary World Languages Methods
description: Secondary World Languages Methods gives an overview of instructional theory, methods, and materials in World Languages and helps students develop teaching strategies and address the Colorado content standards. Prer., Admission into TELP professional year.

name: School Experience - Secondary
description: Pre-student teaching field experience. Summer: Teaching in a summer program for area secondary schools. Fall: 8 weeks in a PDS middle school site and 8 weeks in a PDS high school site observing, assisting, teaching. Prer., EDUC 4600. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Secondary - Student Teaching
description: Secondary education students, in consultation with members of the school of education faculty, will be assigned to a secondary professional development school for full-day teaching for a period of sixteen weeks. During this time students will demonstrate, through direct experience, competency and understanding of the teaching-learning process. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Summit. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Educational Applications of Learning Theory
description: A seminar designed to introduce a spectrum of current theories of learning including elements of cognitive psychology, social learning theory and behaviorism. Students will be expected to read extensively and lead discussion of their areas of investigation.

name: Human Growth and Development
description: Provides a broad understanding of life span theories of human development; understanding the nature and needs of individuals at all developmental levels; normal and abnormal human behavior indicators; personality theory and development; and learning theory within cultural contexts. Meets with COUN 5040.

name: Teaching the Creative and Gifted Student
description: This introductory course explores the nature and nurture of gifted children and adolescents. Characteristics, identification, program alternatives, and teaching strategies are addressed as is the gifted child movement.

name: Electrical & Computer Basics
description: Foundational course intended for students with little to no technical background. Basic electrical circuit principles and concepts explored through hands-on projects. Also, basic computer design, operation and programming will be explored through hands-on projects. Does not count towards ECE major. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Explore-Physical and Natural World.

name: Introduction to Robotics
description: An introductory course in robotics integrating hardware and software. Students build robots with sensors & motors and write programs to control the robot. Students learn fundamental sequential C programming skills. Students use Arduino Robot kits to implement their designs. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Writing Intensive. Prer., ECE majors should take ECE 1001 with Compass WI, non-ECE majors should take ECE 1002 w/out Compass WI, or permission of instructor. Meets with ECE 1002. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Introduction to Robotics
description: An introductory course in robotics integrating hardware and software. Students build robots with sensors & motors and write programs to control the robot. Students learn fundamental sequential C programming skills. Students use Arduino Robot kits to implement their designs. Prer., ECE majors should take ECE 1001 with Compass WI, non-ECE majors should take ECE 1002 w/out Compass WI, or permission of instructor. Meets with ECE 1001. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Computer-Based Modeling and Methods of Engineering
description: Emphasis on algorithm development for solving engineering problems. Advanced topics in the C programming language: arrays, user functions, pointers, data structures, and file I/O. Prer., ECE 1001 or ECE 1002, MATH 1320 or MATH 1350, College of Engineering students only.

name: Logic Circuits I
description: Learn fundamentals of digital logic circuits, number systems, logic gates, and Boolean Algebra. Students will design combinational logic circuits. Coreq., ECE 1421 for Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering students. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Logic Circuits Laboratory I
description: Through a series of laboratory sessions, students will design and build combinational logic circuits, gaining practical experience with discrete components. Coreq., ECE 1411 for Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering students.

name: Intermediate Robotics Programming
description: Continuation of ECE 1001/1002, with additional components and sensors, using more advanced topics in the C programming language; arrays, user functions, pointers, data structures and file I/O. Prer., ECE 1001 or ECE 1002 or Permission of Instructor.

name: Computer Based Modeling in C
description: Emphasis on algorithm development and H/W implementation of C programs for solving engineering problems. Students learn to write structured C programs using: arrays, user functions, pointers, data structures, file 1/0 and multi-file compiles. Prer., ECE 1001 or ECE 1002 or Permission of Instructor. Meets with DASE 2021. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring, Summer

name: Introduction to Physical Electronics
description: Introduction to electronic device materials science. Topics include crystals, metals, alloys, insulators, semiconductors, conduction, quantum considerations. Ethical and professional issues with materials in the global, economic, environmental, and societal contexts are studied. Coreq., PES 2130. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Circuits and Systems I
description: Modeling and analysis of analog circuits and linear systems. Kirchoff’s current and voltage laws. Uses time-domain methods and s-domain transfer functions to solve differential equations of first and second-order RLC circuits with op amps. Transient and steady-state response to steps and complex exponentials. Zero-input, zero-state, and initial-state response. Introduction to circuit simulation. Prer., ECE 2610, Coreq., MATH 3400. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Spring, Summer

name: Circuit Analysis I
description: Modeling and analysis of electrical devices and circuits, including operational amplifiers. Transient and steady state response using classical differential equation methods. Impulse and step responses. Prer., MATH 1360, ECE 1021. Coreq., MATH 2350, PES 2130. College of Engineering students only.

name: Logic Circuits II
description: Learn design and implement synchronous sequential logic circuits. Mealy and Moore machine, states assignment, state reduction and encoding. Verilog HDL as modeling and verifying tool for both combinational and sequential logic circuits in a series of laboratories. Prer., ECE 1411. Coreq., ECE 1021, ECE 2021 or CS 2060. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Introduction to Signals and Systems
description: Mathematical representation of signals and systems; spectrum representation; representation of signals by sample values; discrete-time filter characterization and response; the z-transform; continuous-time signals and linear, time-invariant systems; frequency response; continuous-time Fourier transform and application to system analysis. MATLAB basics with application to signals and systems. Includes lectures,  demonstrations, and laboratory assignments. Prer., MATH 1360 and (ECE 1021 or ECE 2021 or CS 2060) or instructor approval. Course typically offered: Fall, Spring

name: Electronic Projects
description: Designed for non-engineering majors. In the Fall semester, the principles of “How We Communicate” are introduced through hands-on building and testing of radio circuits. In the Spring semester, the principles of “How We Control” are introduced through hands-on building, programming, and testing of micro-controllers. The history, personalities, social and cultural impacts, economic and business impacts, and sustainability issues are integrated into the lecture material for the target technology. Prer., Freshman level science course.

name: Advanced Robotics
description: Explore advanced robotics topics through the project management process. Project based class with scheduled milestones, min. lecture, max. applied. For the final project, each student will build and program a small autonomous vehicle to navigate between GPS coordinates. Prer., ECE 2021 or DASE 2021 or Permission of Instructor. Meets with DASE 3003. Course typically offered: Spring

name: C++ and GUI Programming
description: A hands-on course in C++ programming and GUI development integrating hardware and software. Students implement programs on a Raspberry Pi with a Touchscreen. Basic computer architecture and the Linux OS are covered. Min. lecture, max. applied. Prer., DASE 2021 or ECE 2021 or ECE 1021 or Permission of Instructor. Meets with DASE 3005.

name: Python & Jupyter Programming
description: A hands-on course in Python programming and Jupyter Notebook development using various add-on libraries; integrating hardware and software. Students implement programs on a Raspberry Pi with a touch screen. Basic computer architecture and the Linux OS are covered. Min. lecture, max. applied. Prer., ECE 2021 or ECE 1021 or DASE 2021 or Permission of Instructor. Meets with DASE 3007.

name: IoT on AWS
description: A hands-on course in Amazon Web Services (AWS) Internet of Things (loT) programming; integrating hardware and software. Students initiate programs on a Raspberry Pi, through AWS, to different types of loT devices. Min. lecture, max. applied. Prer., ECE 1021 or ECE 2021 or DASE 2021 or Permission of Instructor. Meets with DASE 3009.

name: Semiconductor Devices I
description: An introduction to semiconductor devices used in modern microelectronic technologies. The course objective is to provide an understanding of the fundamental physical principles and concepts underlying the operation and use of the most important semiconductor devices. Prer., ECE 2050, and either ECE 2205 or ECE 2210. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Electromagnetic Fields I
description: Static electric and magnetic field analysis, Poisson’s and Laplace’s equations, steady electric current, fields of steady electric currents, ferromagnetic materials, boundary-value problems for static fields, time-varying electric and magnetic fields, and Maxwell’s equations and wave equations. Relationship between field and circuit theory. Prer., ECE 2205 or ECE 2210. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Electromagnetic Fields II
description: Electromagnetic wave propagation in dielectric and conducting media: solutions to the wave equations, transmission lines, waveguides and resonators, antennas and radiation, uniform and non-uniform plane waves. Design involving considerations of electromagnetic fields. Prer., ECE 3110, MATH 3400. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Electronic Projects Lab
description: Fall offering - operation, building, and testing radio projects. Spring offering - operation, building, and testing of uC projects.  College of Engineering students only.

name: Circuits and Systems II
description: Circuit analysis in the frequency domain. Phasors, sinusoidal steady-state response, and impedance, Fourier series/transforms and Laplace transforms. Design of active and passive analog filters. Includes lectures, demonstrations, and laboratory assignments. Prer., ECE 2205 or consent of instructor. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Electronics I
description: Semiconductor device use in electronic circuits. Topics include amplifier theory, advanced op-­amp circuits, diode circuits and applications, MOS and BJT transistor operation, characteristics, basic transistor amplifiers. Prer., ECE 2205 or ECE 2210. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Electronics II
description: Transistor power amplifiers, basic IC circuits, differential and multi-stage amplifier design, high-frequency models, frequency response, feedback, design of IC op-amps. Prer., ECE 2205 and ECE 3210. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Electronics Laboratory I
description: Electronics test and measurement techniques including the use and limits of: power supplies, signal generators, multimeters, oscilloscopes, probes, automation. Op-amps and op-amp circuits, diodes, sensors, transistor characterization and amplifiers. Written reports emphasize results, issues. Coreq., ECE 3210. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Electronics Laboratory II
description: Amplifier design from theory, simulation, breadboard, through pcb design, build, solder and characterization. Advanced transistor amplifier build and characterization; single-stage, multi-stage, frequency response, feedback. Written reports emphasis on documenting results and issues. Prer., ECE 3230. Coreq., ECE 3220. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Microprocessor Systems Laboratory
description: Introduction to microprocessor development systems and foundations of system design. Assembly language will be used in the development. Use of high-level languages will also be discussed. Prer., ECE 1411. Coreq., ECE 3430. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Introduction to Microcomputer Systems
description: Design of microcomputer systems including assembly language programming and interfacing techniques. Emphasis is on the practical application of microcomputers as solutions to engineering problems. Prer., ECE 2411. Coreq., ECE 3420. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Microcomputer Systems Laboratory
description: Experiments are performed to program and interface microcomputer systems to design and implement microcomputer-based systems. Emphasis is on the application of the microcomputer as a tool to solve control and data acquisition problems. Prer., ECE 2411, ECE 3430. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Linear System Theory
description: Characterization of linear systems by impulse response, convolution, transfer function. Linear differential equations and linear difference equations as models. Applications to circuits, electromechanical systems, etc. Transform methods include: Fourier series, Fourier transforms, and Laplace transforms. Introduction to state variables, and the state transition matrix. Use of a variety of models in design. Prer., ECE 3210, MATH 3400. Coreq., ECE 3520. College of Engineering students only.

name: Engineering Probability and Statistics
description: An introduction to probability and statistics with application to solving engineering problems. Includes the axioms of probability, random variables, density functions, distributions functions, expectations. Gaussian random variables, bivariate random variables, sums of independent random variables. Estimation of sample mean and variance. Monte Carlo simulation, binomial, hypergeometric, Poisson counting processes, confidence intervals, reliability, failure rates, the Weibull model, the log-normal model, estimation using regression. Introduction to random processes. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirements: Navigate; Writing Intensive. Prer., MATH 2350. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Engineering Probability and Statistics
description: An introduction to probability and statistics with application to solving engineering problems. Equivalent to ECE 3610, but with no Compass requirements. Prer., MATH 2350. College of Engineering students only.

name: Power Systems I
description: Basic concepts and analytical methods in three-phase electric power systems: single-phase equivalent models; per-unit system of calculations; power, apparent power, and energy; basic properties of power systems elements; short-circuit current; voltage drop; and losses. Includes lectures and demonstrations. Prer., ECE 3205. Coreq. ECE 3110. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Electrical or Computer Engineering Internship
description: Internship with company, non-profit, government or academic institutions with a minimum of 140 hrs for 3 credits. Requires prior agreement between direct supervisor and professor; documentation includes learning goals, schedules, and deliverables. Cannot be at a student’s regular work. Prer., Junior standing and 3.0 GPA.

name: Semiconductor Devices II
description: Advanced study of the electrical and transport properties of semiconducting and solid state devices and integrated device structures. Topics include: pn junction device structures, non-ideal effects in small geometry Mosfets, compound semiconducting devices, CCDs, negative conductance microwave devices. Prer., ECE 3020. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5020. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Introductory VLSI Fabrication Laboratory
description: Various types of VLSI fabrication processes such as thermal oxidation, rapid thermal annealing, diffusion, physical vapor deposition, ion implantation, photolithography and etching. In addition, students will use a variety of device characterization techniques available in the laboratory. Prer., ECE 4020, ECE 4080. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Microelectronics IC Fabrication Laboratory
description: Independent experimental project in which students are expected to acquire the theoretical understanding of modern IC fabrication process, perform the IC processing and supporting measurements, and write detailed laboratory reports. Students should take ECE 4050 before ECE 4896. Prer., ECE 4020, ECE 4080. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5050.

name: Electronic Properties of Materials
description: Principles and applications of the electrical, optical, magnetic, and thermal properties of engineering electronic materials. The treatment is designed for students specializing in the areas of microelectronics, solid state, and electromagnetics. Prer., ECE 3020. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5070.

name: VLSI Processing
description: Introductory study of the various processes such as oxidation, diffusion, epitaxy, ion-implantation, photolithography, CVD, plasma processing, etc., used in contemporary fabrication of modern microelectronic technologies; use and understanding of process modeling programs used in design, fabrication, and simulation of MOSFET and bipolar microelectronics technologies. Prer., ECE 3020. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5080.

name: Nanotechnology I
description: Application to advanced semiconductors and oxide electronics in which electron-electron interactions dictate device operations is the final goal of the series. Advanced device technology in the nanometer scale era and advances in strongly correlated electron devices need specialized knowledge in many areas of quantum physics which involve Non-Equilibrium Green’s Function (NEGF) formalism and advanced techniques of quantum field theory in condensed matter. Students pursuing MSEE and PhD programs are encouraged to have knowledge in these formalisms in order to conduct research in advanced areas of device physics. The treatment is essentially an engineering application of fundamental formalisms in practical applications. Only advanced undergraduates with an interest in MSEE and PhD in Physics or Electrical Engineering may take this course with instructor permission. Meets with ECE 5095.

name: Electromagnetic Theory and Applications
description: An intermediate level fields course beginning with the classical development of Maxwell’s equations and the Wave equation. Included are electrostatics, the steady magnetic field, plane-wave propagation, Poynting’s vector, guided waves, transmission lines, wave guides, the interaction of fields and matter, and concluding with an introduction to the subject of radiation. Dirac-delta and Dyadic Green’s function methods of problem solution are treated. Prer., ECE 3120. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5110. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Antenna Engineering
description: Antenna engineering theory based on electromagnetic radiation is introduced. Various antennas including linear wire, aperture/horn, printed-circuit, and arrays are introduced. The design, fabrication, and measurement of antennas are covered. Prer. or Coreq., ECE 3120. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5120. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Microwave Measurements Laboratory
description: Experiments with transmission lines and waveguide systems. Infrared imaging of electromagnetic fields. Measurement of antenna fields. Exposure to equipment and techniques used in microwave measurements. Design of microwave circuits. Coreq., ECE 3120. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5150. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Electric Machines Lab
description: Laboratory experiments to identify electrical machines characteristics and performance. Coreq., ECE 4162. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Electric Machines
description: The course material covers transformers analysis and operation, steady-state and dynamic analysis of rotating machines, synchronous, DC machines and poly-phase induction motors. Prer., ECE 3205. Coreq., ECE 4160. Meets with ECE 5162. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Advanced Microwave Measurement Laboratory
description: Advanced study of microwave circuits, experiments, procedures, measurement techniques. Topics include Friis equation, cascade gain/noise, antenna directivity/gain, saturation, receiver design, antennas, ERP, near-far fields, thermal noise, and electronic warfare. Meets with ECE 5180. Prer., ECE 4150/5150.

name: Advanced Digital Design Laboratory
description: A design laboratory focusing on the design of digital systems in Verilog using the Digilent Spartan 3 FPGA prototyping board. A contemporary design environment consisting of the Xilinx ISE tool for implementation and ModelSim/QuestaSim for simulation will be utilized. Prer., ECE 4242. College of Engineering students only. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Rapid Prototyping with FPGAs
description: Field programmable gate arrays (FPGAs) are an important part of the overall design flow for application-specific integrated circuits (ASICs) because they offer the potential of allowing cheap hardware prototypes to be built to meet a narrow window of opportunity. They also offer novel, programmable architectures. This course will focus on the combined use of FPGAs and modern synthesis tools to develop rapid prototypes of ASICs. Includes a team project. Prer., ECE 4242. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5211. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Analog IC Design
description: A fundamental analog circuit design course that establishes relationships between semiconductor device theory, semiconductor processing technologies and the electrical and functional performance requirements of modern analog integrated circuits. Includes design project. Prer., ECE 3020, ECE 3220, ECE 3240. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5220.

name: Deep Learning
description: An introduction to deep learning. A range of topics will be covered from basic deep learning algorithms, architectures, for deep learning, and applications to problem domains. Prer., ECE 1021, ECE 2021, and CS 2060 or instructor permission. Meets with ECE 5222. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Analog Filter Design
description: Theory, specification, design, and simulation of active and passive analog filters based on modern integrated circuit technology and VLSI Design I design philosophy. Prer., ECE 3220. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5230.

name: Advanced Digital Design Methodology
description: Focuses on modern digital design practice using computer-based design tools and then considers key steps in a modern design flow, with particular attention to the use of behavioral models in hardware description languages as a stepping stone to combinational and sequential logic synthesis. The Verilog language will be presented, along with ancillary topics of functional verification, testbench generation, timing analysis, fault simulation, and design for testability. Design examples will include microcontrollers, finite state machines for datapath control, serial and parallel communication protocol controllers, and typical architectures of synchronous computational units. Prer., ECE 2411. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5242. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Microwave Circuit Design
description: An introduction to the design and analysis of microwave circuits both passive and active. Topics include microwave circuit analysis, measurement methods, transmission line structures, material properties, lumped elements, discontinuities, terminations, attenuators, directional couplers, hybrids, power dividers, impedance transformers, filters, mixers, switches, phase shifters, and amplifiers. Coreq., ECE 3120. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5250. Course typically offered: Fall

name: Mixed Signal IC Design
description: Design of data converters, switch capacitor filters, high performance opamps, phase locked loops, oscillators. Prer., ECE 4220 or ECE 5220. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5260.

name: CMOS Radio Frequency Integrated Circuit Design
description: CMOS based high Frequency amplifier design, s-parameters, voltage references, noise, low noise amplifier (LNA), mixers, RF power amplifiers, phaselocked loops, oscillators and synthesizers, transmitter and receiver architectures and RFID systems. Prer., ECE 3110, ECE 3210, ECE 3220. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5270.

name: Advanced Verification Methodology
description: Verification of electronic systems consumes 70% of the development cycle. This course teaches students how to develop high-quality verification environments with SystemVerilog and how to use advanced verification techniques such as assertions and coverage for digital systems. Prer., ECE 4242. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5280.

name: Research In Advanced Topics In Engineering
description: This course will enable conducting research in various advanced topics in engineering: e.g., embedded/digital systems (FPGA/ASIC); data analytics/mining; machine learning and AI; hardware cybersecurity; adaptive cognitive radio; embedded control systems. Includes a final project, proposal, etc. Prer., ECE 4242/5252 or ECE 4211/5211 or ECE 4330/5330 or approval from the instructor. Course typically offered: Spring

name: Fault Detection & Design for Testability
description: Stuck-at fault modeling. Test generation for combinational circuits-Boolean difference, D algorithm, PODEM, FAN, critical path. Fault dominance and equivalence. Test generation for synchronous sequential circuits. Cost functions used in test generation. Fault simulation. Basics of design for testability. Prer., ECE 3430. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5320.

name: Embedded Systems Design
description: Introduction to embedded systems including real time fault-tolerant significance. Study the hardware and software techniques to designing embedded system, including study of various embedded operating systems, embedded controllers and digital signal processing hardware. Study existing embedded systems. Prer., ECE 3430, CS 1450, or consent of instructor. College of Engineering students only. Meets with ECE 5330. Course typically offered: Fall

name: VLSI Circuit Design I
description: Design considerations for MOS integrated circuits with an emphasis on CMOS technology and the relationships between semiconductor device theory, semiconductor processing technologies, and the electrical and functional performance requirements of modern digital IC circuits. Physical behavior of CMOS transistors and integrated circuits, CMOS processing technology, CMOS circuit and logic design, design rules and structured design methodology. Prer., ECE 3020, ECE 3210.
