description: Courses will vary and can be repeated for credit up to 9 credits as long as the topics are different. Prer., WEST 1010 (formerly WEST 2010).

name: Selected Topics in History and Women
description: These courses are usually taught on a one-time basis. The subject matter will change from year to year and will cover an important but rarely taught subject in history.

name: Spiked: Spike Lee’s Cinema
description: This course analyzes ways in which social identities are represented in American film, particularly through the cinematic lenses of director, producer, actor, and activist Spike Lee. Although this course will focus particularly on the interosculating representations presented by Lee, we will also contextualize his representations as elements of greater American filmic narratives around race, class, sexuality, and so forth gleaned from a variety of perspectives. Approved for LAS Cultural Diversity requirements. Prer., WEST 1010 (formerly WEST 2010). Meets with SOC 4920, SOC 5920.

name: Juvenile Delinquency
description: Factors involved in delinquent behavior. Problems of adjustments of delinquents and factors in treatment and post-treatment and adjustment. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Inclusiveness (Global/Diversity). Meets with SOC 4960 and SOC 5960. Prer., A minimum of 60 credit hours completed or consent of instructor.

name: WEST Honors Capstone Preparatory
description: This course prepares students to complete an honors capstone research/creative project in the subsequent semester. Students will: commit to specific research questions or creative and/or methodological design, have one-on-one meetings with instructor for project feedback and approval, and complete all IRB requirements. Prer., WEST 1010. Coreq., WEST 3400.

name: WEST Honors Capstone
description: The WEST senior honors capstone course is designed for WEST majors interested in pursuing departmental honors to demonstrate their cumulative learning of WEST theory, research methods, and substantive concepts and topics in the field. Students will: complete their honors capstone research/creative project and give a presentation of their project. Prer., WEST 1010, WEST 3400, and WEST 4980.

name: Women’s and Ethnic Studies Capstone Course
description: One-credit add-on course open to WEST majors to complete an synthesis project and presentation meeting the capstone/summit requirement. The WEST senior capstone course is designed to demonstrate cumulative learning of theory, methods, and substantive integration of intersectional scholarship. Approved for Compass Curriculum requirement: Summit. Prer., WEST 3400, senior standing, and permission of instructor.

name: Independent Study in WEST
description: Provides an opportunity for advanced students with good scholastic records to independently pursue the study of a subject of special interest. Prer., WEST 1010 (formerly WEST 2010) and consent of Director.

name: Independent Study - Research and Creative Works
description: Provides an opportunity to conduct research with faculty by one or more students on topics determined by a faculty member. Prer., Consent of instructor required.

name: Writing Portfolio Assessment
description: PORT 3000 fulfills the Writing Portfolio assessment required of all undergraduate students, prior to graduation, to demonstrate writing competency. Students should take the PORT 3000 course one to two semesters before the semester they plan to graduate. In PORT 3000 students must submit two to three papers to be scored by faculty raters. The course has no meetings and is graded as satisfactory/unsatisfactory based on the quality of the papers submitted. More information is available at: http://www.uccs.edu/~writingportfolio/. Prer., ENGL 1410 or TCID 2080 or TCID 2090 (formerly ENGL 2080, ENGL 2090) or INOV 2100.

name: Professional Portfolio
description: PORT 4000 guides students through developing a professional portfolio. The primary assignment is to develop an electronic portfolio displaying the skills gained during a student’s undergraduate experience which can be shared with prospective employers, clients, graduate schools, etc. Prer., 60 credit hours and completion of Core Writing Two (ENGL 1410, TCID 2080, TCID 2090, INOV 2100 or equivalent).
